And the polycrown here for a thousand. But that's because it was damaged at the edges. But collectors can pay many thousands of kroner. We see that you have framed them and have them on the walls. We have put them here to get a better overview. Hans Jacob, you have framed this one. Is it special?

It's a slightly cheeky motif. There are two women on each side. Nicely decorated, slightly plump ladies, but they just go out. In the middle we have a small, puzzled man, but he does something, he hurts. That's what my sister doesn't quite agree with. No, I think it's in the rudest category.

It is very decorative. You also use the tiles as a table top. It is incredibly durable and can withstand hot things. It is a Dutch landscape. Boats, swans, sailboats, windmills. Typical Dutch.

We have attached a story to each of the tiles. Is that what is important to you? Yes, so we don't sell them. We have to get back to our treak soon. Do you know what it is? No. Something that was made in Hallingdal in the old days.

You touched juniper berries all day, and got a kind of snot that the children chewed on. She is a dentist. Yes, the dentists have to live too. Now I understand more why there are two molars there.

What is the symbolism, two molars, a broken pen. Two broken tiles. I sat and read between the cackles. Now we say cackles. Even me. Tiles it is. Two broken tiles.

Then I found my grandfather's old amber pen shaft, which was broken. When I went to school, I wanted to be a journalist. But I didn't have the best grades in Norwegian, so I started dental school. The first year we were given the bottom molar. We also got a small block of ivory.

Then we sat down with a woodworking machine and had to make an exact copy down to the millimetre. And I can assure you it has cost blood, sweat and tears.

Then we have to return to the treak. Now you have cooked juniper berries for many hours today. Where have the juniper berries gone? There. They are silted away. There is a lot of dirt. One should have a liquid that is free of all turbidity. It is unappetizing to eat.

What else should you include? Gerd has added the brown sugar. Demerara sugar. But you can also use normal brown sugar. Then 400 grams of brown cheese. And a quarter of a liter of cream in this recipe.

It looks like normal caramels, but with juniper berries as a starting point. It must be boiled until we get such a consistency that we can make shafts from it. So this is old crap from Hallingdal? We got the recipe from Ågot Veslehaug in Geilo.

Gerd, I have heard that it is very healthy to eat crickets. But that juniper berries are dangerous, because there is turpentine in it. Yes, but you don't eat so much of it that it matters. It used to matter

because they boiled the tops of the bushes. It then became a guild, to wash wooden carts in. In old household books it says that washing wooden carts in this is much better than in soda.

You will get a bit of a job if you have to wash Frode's wooden carts. How long should this cook? We will show that. This has now boiled, but is too hot to roll out. It should boil until it has a consistency ... How long has it been here now? No, people just have to learn that.

One must be patient. Then you have to spend almost the whole day. It takes at least 2-3 hours before it turns into such a brown sauce. A little thicker, maybe. Get to know. Then it must be cooled. It must be rolled.

Now this has stood and cooled, and obtained such a consistency. Then I should be able to make a shaft. I have heard that on the farms in Hallingdal and on the farms, they had a lot of this snot. A boy or girl who went on an errand received this as a reward.

Now we have a lump here. You can shape it, roll it, very cleverly on a piece of baking paper. Then it won't stick. Now we can roll it out into a shaft like that, as we said. A little rolling and a little shaping. Why don't you make small, square caramels? No, this is how it should be done.

Then you just divide it up, or eat them as they are. It is clear that one can divide them into smaller pieces. They probably did too, but tradition dictates. It was more work, even with small pieces. This was common at the time when you could pick juniper berries.

Then this was made up, and it was often used for Christmas decorations. After all, Brake was known from literature from the earliest times. It had a cult following. They sprinkled bracken on the floor after it was washed, so that the coal would smell good.

At the same time, they used them at funerals. They strewed them on the road where the hearse was to drive. It was like a tribute to the person who had died. It was quite common on the farms, I can remember that myself. You may have to have a little water on the spoon when you pick it up.

Then it drops the spoon. Should this just lie? Now it has become cold. Now Gerd will wrap it in butter paper. Does it have to be stored or can it be eaten now? It should be cold, it's not yet, but Gerd can show you. It has to be cold, that's important. But I have to taste it.

We'll take the recipe, because it was a bit much now. The bracken berries are boiled in water, so that it covers the berries. You have to use it all day, because it will boil and boil. Under a lid, so it doesn't reduce. After five hours with the lid off, the berries are crushed.

Cook for another hour, strain, and then get a blackberry juice. Then add brown sugar, cream and brown cheese. Boil it in, so it becomes as thick as this. Cools it down until you can start working with it. It was a little warm, but now it's colder. Here is something that was cooked earlier.

You can make such nice doodles. You can shape it as you like. Wasn't it good? Yes, but it's easier to buy caramels. You don't get caramels with a bitter taste. If you have time, get out and pick some juniper berries. You can get the recipe here with us.

Have you tasted treak? No, is it good? It will be like crackers or caramels with a good juniper flavor. Forest flavor. Yes. But it takes forever to make it. To eat it too. I have one each for you if we can get another visa. We must be able to do that.

We have a great book here, written by Rolf Hindhammer. "A fiddler and a treasure trove" is the title of the book. He has collected songs and songs, secular and spiritual songs from his district, Angvik in Nordmøre. He had a lot after his father, Arne Hindhammer, and other players. Now you have made the job much easier.

Instead of traveling around and looking for old proverbs, you just look up Rolf Hindhammar's book. One could go on for years, there is so much great stuff. There are a few examples of money laundering that we have come across. They are available in different varieties around the country. The songs together were played and sung in different ways.

Each district had its own interpretations and its own form. This is the Hindhammer tradition. He himself has written over 200 melodies for traditional texts. Lots of nice stuff here. And now we end with something from here? Yes, with a spiritual sage.

column2:
Et gammelt bønnedikt som Rolf Hindhammar har satt tone til. Hva heter visa? "En liten aftensang." Sven, er det et gammelt trøorgel som står der? Veslemøy syns jeg trengte litt trim.

Istedenfor ergometersykkel ble det salmesykkel. Det er ingen dum idé, for et trøorgel må en trø hele tida. En får bra trim av det. Dette er en skikkelig, flott antikvitet. Skal vi si mer om trøorgelet? Det er en oppfinnelse fra 1800-tallet. Populært fram til 2. verdenskrig.

Da tok el-orgelet over, men det ... Vi sier ikke mer om det. Da står det bare igjen for oss å takke for i kveld. Vi skal avslutte med "En liten aftensang". Så ses vi igjen om 14 dager.
column3:
An old prayer poem to which Rolf Hindhammar has set the tone. What is a visa? "A little evening song." Sven, is there an old wooden organ standing there? Veslemøy I think I needed a little trim.

Instead of an ergometer bicycle, it became a pedal bicycle. It's not a bad idea, because a wood organ has to be wood all the time. One gets a good trim from it. This is a real, great antique. Shall we say more about the tree organ? It is an invention from the 19th century. Popular until World War II.

Then the electric organ took over, but that ... We say no more about it. Then it only remains for us to give thanks for tonight. We will end with "A little evening song". See you again in 14 days.

column2:
I kveld skal vi hjem til Inger Johanne Rygh og Hans Jacob Haga. Søskenparet som samler på håndmalte hollandske fliser. Det som også blir kalt for kakler. Her ser du litt av samlinga, men vi skal tilbake til dem om en stund. I gryta til Gerd og Frode putrer det allerede.

Jeg syns det lukter fjell. Det lukter brakebær, einebær. I dag skal vi lage snop av dette. "Treak" kalles det, et snop fra Hallingdal.

Disse bærene er sorte, men plukker du dem nå, skal de være blå. Einebærene modnes på to år. Det første året grønne, og blå det neste. Når disse virker sorte, er det fordi det ligger et blått vokslag utenpå

når en finner dem ute, men det går av. Det er en regle om det: "Når alle einebær er sort, giftes alle jenter bort." Det går nemlig ikke an, verken det ene eller det andre. Nå er vi i oktober, og nå er det rett tid å plukke einebær. Nå er de på det beste.

Hvor lenge har snopet kokt? I fem timer. Jeg knuser bærene, har på litt mer væske, og koker dem en time til. Da kan du komme tilbake og se hva vi skal gjøre videre. Da ser vi på antikviteter så lenge. Ellen Ørnes, har du satt fram typiske jenteting igjen?

Et lite soveromsmøblement? Det må være feminine innslag også. Det er et miniatyrmøbel fra første halvdel av 1800-tallet. Det ser ikke særlig norsk ut. Jeg tør ikke si hvor det er lagd, men slike ble lagd i Norge også. Som jentene hadde på soverommet. Oppi her er det vel smykker. Ja, tenkte jeg det ikke.

Skjønt dette kunne vært ... Det heter jett, forkullet tre. Svarte steiner. Det ble populært da prins Albert av England døde. Brukt som begravelsessmykker i lang stund framover. Dette er fra 20-tallet eller 1910. Hva skal du ha for dette smykket?

Det er svensk sølvstempel på det, så 1500 kroner, kanskje. Blir de billigere eller dyrere etter som tida går? Dette er vel bare tinn? Nei, det er sølv. Det er jugendsmykker som Georg Jensen lagde mange av i Danmark.

Disse har norske stempel og laget i Norge, begge to. Det andre er laget omkring 1915, litt nybarokke trekk. Det er månestein. Prisen er nok et par tusen kroner, kanskje litt mer. Det er ikke greit for oss menn, som skal holde dere med smykker. Dere er dyre i ... De varer lenge.

Dette er sikkert ikke så dyrt. Emaljesmykker. Sommerfuglene ble laget fra slutten av forrige århundre til i dag. Det er nok fra begynnelsen av århundret en gang. En M og en hammer på baksida, laget av Marius Hammer i Bergen. Den er litt skadet, emaljen tåler jo ikke så mye.

Han jobbet hos David Andersen 1892-1910. Da begynte han sitt eget verksted. Det varte bare i 4 år, for han døde under en blindtarmoperasjon. Hørte dere det, jenter. Rolls Royce innen emaljesmykker. Se i skuffen om du har emaljesmykker med G.G. på baksida.

Det er ikke uvanlig å betale 4000 kroner for dem. Da skal de være helt strøkne uten riper eller skader. Hvis jeg går ute og ser en dame, kan jeg se om hun har en G.G.? En kan ikke se det på utsida? Nei, en må se bakpå. Men det var høy kvalitet på det han lagde.

Har du flere jenteting? Det var ikke flere skuffer. Dette møbelet har jeg ikke satt pris på, men er nok verdt 4000 kr. Ta den ned veldig forsiktig, Kjell. Den er litt lealaus. Hva tror du den er verdt?

For å være litt forsiktig skal du få 350 kroner for den. Det var det han mente, han som solgte den også. Skal en på jakt etter antikviteter, gjelder kunnskap. Jo mer en kan, jo bedre kjøp kan en gjøre. Om det er på auksjoner, loppemarkeder, brukthandlere. Han som eier dette, er veldig dyktig. Han vet hva han ser etter.

Dette så han på et marked, og selgeren kikket litt på det. Kjøperen sier at den er hvit på toppen. Så ser han at det er litt slitasje under og har et eldre preg. Så er det gjort noe rart med den rundt århundreskiftet. Det rare mener du er det stativet den står i.

Selgeren ville ha 250 kroner, og var fornøyd med det. Kjøperen fortet seg inn i bilen, og hjemme fant han fram ei baufil. Så saget han av den i full fart og åpnet den. Der, ganske riktig, fant han det han lette etter. Det var ei skål skjult under her. Ei smørskål fra Gjøvik Glassverk fra 1820-1830-årene.

Den har en omsetningsverdi på 8000-10 000 kroner. For denne blå krukka? Ja, han var heldig med jakta. Fordi den kommer fra Gjøvik Glassverk. Og det ser du på den hvite kanten? Ja, de lagde glass med koboltblått. Men hvis man vil lære noe, må man lese.

Denne serien fra Huitfeldt er små billige bøker. Den koster en hundrelapp. Om Hurdal og Gjøvik Glassverk. For fem år siden kom et blad, "Samler- og antikkbørsen". Her fins artikler om ting du kan lære, se priser og hvor de fins.

Les og lær og inn i skuffer og skap, og se om du har sånne blå krukker. Det står noen fine stoler bak her. Dette er jo ettertraktete ting. Gamle, gode bondeantikviteter. Denne kubbestolen er liten, er det en barnestol? Det ser en både på høyden, og at ikke mange får plass der.

Den er fra Telemark fra 1700-tallet. De hulte ut trestammer, helst de som allerede var råtne. Da var det lettere å jobbe med dem. ê Råtne inni. Men ellers ble jo alltid kubbestolene hult ut, for at de skulle bli lettere å hanskes med. Og for at de ikke så lett skulle sprekke. Jeg vet litt. Det er flott.

De har gjerne timeglassform, og det båndet rundt kanten. Og det skjørtet med riller nedover. Det morsomme med den stolen er at før var de overtroiske og trodde de kunne få hjelp derfra. Det er slått inn mange hvite greier. Det er melketenner når de datt ut.

De slo dem inn i stolen, for da trodde de det vernet mot tannpine. Det er jo morsomt med de stolene. Hva skal du ha for en sånn stol? Fra 5000 og oppover. Etter hvor sjarmerende den er. Det står en fin en her også. Ja, fin og fin ...

Du sier vel at den ikke er så fin, men det er ettertraktete ting. Ja, denne er fin, en gammel stol fra midten av 1700-tallet. Og du vil si at den er litt skabbete. Ja, den mangler en bit her, noe oppå der. Den er antakeligvis fra Gudbrandsdalen. Så gamle ting som ennå eksisterer, er jo ettertraktet, og stiger i pris.

Men den er litt markspist. Jeg har hørt at hvis en tar en markspist ting inn i et tørt, moderne hus, så dør marken med en gang. Men hullene er der uansett, og de er ikke så sjarmerende. Men like verdifull er den. Nei, det er jeg ikke enig i.

Særlig på Østlandet er det ikke midd, så der er de redd for slikt. Da kan vi beholde de fine tingene på Vestlandet. Hvor mye skal du ha for den? 5000 kroner. Det er ganske mye. Et restaureringsobjekt. Det dobbelte hvis den hadde vært helt strøken og sjarmerende.

Det stod en gammel ting bak her. Dette er også ettertraktede ting. Du vet hva det er? Det har vel vært salt i den. Den ville jeg ikke hatt om du kastet den etter meg. Vil du ikke ha den? Nei, det er litt for grovt for meg. Du skal bare ha smykker og glass. Det er greit, da kan jeg ta den.

Veslemøy og Sven. Er ikke det en flott liten bondeantikvitet? Er det hatten din? Det er vel noe å ha blomster i. Den hang på veggen, og så hadde man salt oppi her. Ettertraktet ting. Folk betaler 500-600 kroner for en sånn.

Du skal få en oppgave i stedet. Så langt ut i oktober, og så har du fått på deg sommerkjolen. Hvis jeg sier Doris von Kappelhoff, hva tenker du da? Jeg kjenner bare én Doris, og det er Doris Day. Var det henne? Doris von Kappelhoff.

Hadde du bilder av henne? Ikke jeg, men mange andre. Hun var jo kjempestjerne i 50-åra og litt inn i 60-åra. Da var hun stor stjerne i USA og andre steder. Hun skulle egentlig bli danserinne. Hun og moren reiste fra Seattle til Los Angeles for å ta dansetimer.

Så ble bilen påkjørt av et tog, så Doris Day ødela foten sin. Så hun ble sangerinne isteden. Aldri danserinne. Men hun spilte jo i mange filmer. Hun sang veldig fint. 39 filmer, men hun var jo veldig flink til å synge. Det er som skuespiller hun ble mest kjent.

Vi skal frem til en sang, og du kan sikkert gjette hvilken. Av Doris Day? Hva tenker jeg på da? Que sera, sera? Da vet du kanskje filmen også? Nei, jeg kan ikke vite alt. "Mannen som visste for meget."

Det kom også en norsk versjon. Det var Nora Brockstedt som sang den da. Det var i 1956, det samme året som den ble berømt i USA. Han som skrev den, var Arne Bendiksen.

Nå skal vi se på hollandske håndmalte fliser. Vi er hos søskenparet Hans Jacob Haga og Inger Johanne Rygh. Nå må jeg innledningsvis innrømme at jeg i begynnelsen kom til å omtale dette som kakler. Men det er feil. Kakler ble laget til ovner.

Her er en kakkel, den er hul på baksiden for å bevare varmen. Mens dere samler på hollandske fliser. Men da må jeg spørre hva hollandske fliser er. De ble laget allerede fra 1600-tallet i Holland. Håndmalte fliser som ble brukt til dekorasjon på veggene.

Men de hadde også en pedagogisk funksjon. Bibelske motiver, elefanter, som man ikke så i Holland. Det var datidens fjernsyn som de så på om kvelden. Vis meg noen som de satt og diskuterte. Vi har noen som bare viste dagliglivet.

En jeger, en handelsmann osv. Så er det mer barokke fantasier: En engel som hopper tau. Det er et bibelsk motiv, jeg trodde alle hadde det. Ikke så veldig bibelsk med en engel som hopper tau.
column3:
Tonight we are going home to Inger Johanne Rygh and Hans Jacob Haga. The pair of siblings who collect hand-painted Dutch tiles. What is also called tiles. Here you can see a bit of the collection, but we will return to them in a while. Gerd and Frode's cauldron is already simmering.

I think it smells like mountains. It smells like blackberry, juniper. Today we are going to make snoop out of this. "Treak" is what it's called, a snoop from Hallingdal.

These berries are black, but if you pick them now, they should be blue. The juniper berries ripen in two years. The first year green, and blue the next. When these appear black, it is because there is a layer of blue wax on the outside

when you find them outside, but it goes off. There is a rule about it: "When all the juniper berries are black, all the girls are married off." Because it doesn't work, neither one nor the other. Now we are in October, and now is the right time to pick juniper berries. Now they are at their best.

How long has the snop been cooking? For five hours. I crush the berries, add a little more liquid, and cook them for another hour. Then you can come back and see what we are going to do next. Then we look at antiques for so long. Ellen Ørnes, have you presented typical girly things again?

A small piece of bedroom furniture? There must be feminine elements as well. It is a miniature piece of furniture from the first half of the 19th century. It doesn't look very Norwegian. I dare not say where it was made, but such were made in Norway as well. Like the girls had in the bedroom. Up here, it's probably jewelry. Yeah, I didn't think so.

Although this could be ... It's called jet, charred wood. Black stones. It became popular when Prince Albert of England died. Used as funeral jewelry for a long time to come. This is from the 1920s or 1910. What should you get for this piece of jewellery?

There is a Swedish silver stamp on it, so NOK 1,500, maybe. Do they get cheaper or more expensive as time goes on? Surely this is just tin? No, it's silver. It is Art Nouveau jewelry that Georg Jensen made many of in Denmark.

These have a Norwegian stamp and were made in Norway, both. The other was made around 1915, with a slightly neo-baroque feature. It's moonstone. The price is probably a couple of thousand kroner, maybe a little more. It's not good for us men, who have to keep you with jewellery. You are expensive in ... They last a long time.

This is certainly not that expensive. Enamel jewellery. The butterflies were made from the end of the last century until today. It is probably from the beginning of the century sometime. An M and a hammer on the back, made by Marius Hammer in Bergen. It's a little damaged, the enamel doesn't hold up very well.

He worked at David Andersen 1892-1910. Then he started his own workshop. It only lasted 4 years, because he died during an appendectomy. Did you hear that, girls? The Rolls Royce of enamel jewellery. Look in the drawer to see if you have enamel jewelery with GG on the back.

It is not unusual to pay NOK 4,000 for them. Then they must be completely ironed without scratches or damage. If I go out and see a lady, can I see if she has a GG? You can't see it on the outside? No, you have to look behind. But what he made was of high quality.

Do you have more girly things? There were no more drawers. I have not valued this piece of furniture, but it is probably worth NOK 4,000. Take it down very carefully, Kjell. It is a bit dishonest. What do you think it's worth?

To be a little careful, you should get NOK 350 for it. That's what he meant, he who sold it too. If you are looking for antiques, knowledge is important. The more you can, the better purchase you can make. Whether it's at auctions, flea markets, second-hand dealers. The person who owns this is very skilled. He knows what he's looking for.

He saw this at a market, and the seller took a look at it. The buyer says it is white on top. Then he sees that there is some wear underneath and has an older feel. Then something strange was done to it around the turn of the century. The strange thing you mean is the stand it is in.

The seller wanted NOK 250, and was happy with that. The buyer hurried into the car, and at home he found a hacksaw. Then he sawed it off at full speed and opened it. There, sure enough, he found what he was looking for. There was a bowl hidden under here. A butter dish from Gjøvik Glassverk from the 1820s-1830s.

It has a sales value of NOK 8,000-10,000. For this blue jar? Yes, he was lucky with the hunt. Because it comes from Gjøvik Glassverk. And you see that on the white border? Yes, they made glass with cobalt blue. But if you want to learn something, you have to read.

This series from Huitfeldt is small, cheap books. It costs a hundred bucks. About Hurdal and Gjøvik Glassworks. Five years ago, a magazine appeared, "Samler- og antikbørsen". Here are articles about things you can learn, see prices and where to find them.

Read and learn and into drawers and cupboards, and see if you have such blue jars. There are some nice chairs behind here. These are desirable things. Good old farm antiques. This rocking chair is small, is it a child's chair? You can see both at the height, and that not many people can fit there.

It is from Telemark from the 18th century. They hollowed out tree trunks, preferably ones that were already rotten. Then it was easier to work with them. ê Rotten inside. But otherwise, the block chairs were always hollowed out, so that they would be easier to handle. And so that they wouldn't crack so easily. I know a little. It's great.

They often have an hourglass shape, and that band around the edge. And the skirt with grooves down. The funny thing about that chair is that before they were superstitious and thought they could get help from there. A lot of white stuff has been turned in. They are baby teeth when they fall out.

They beat them into the chair, because then they thought it protected against toothache. It's funny with those chairs. What kind of chair would you like? From 5000 and up. By how charming it is. There is a nice one here too. Yes, fine and fine...

You might say it's not that nice, but it's desirable things. Yes, this one is nice, an old chair from the middle of the 18th century. And you'd say it's a little scabby. Yes, it is missing a bit here, something up there. It is probably from Gudbrandsdalen. Such old things that still exist are sought after, and rise in price.

But it is a bit run down. I've heard that if you take a field-eaten thing into a dry, modern house, the field dies immediately. But the holes are there anyway, and they're not that charming. But it is just as valuable. No, I don't agree with that.

Especially in Eastern Norway there are no mites, so there they are afraid of such things. Then we can keep the nice things in Western Norway. How much do you want for it? NOK 5,000. That's quite a lot. A restoration object. Doubly so if it had been completely smooth and charming.

There was an old thing behind here. These are also desirable things. You know what it is? There must have been salt in it. I wouldn't have it if you threw it at me. Don't you want it? No, that's a little too rough for me. You should only have jewelery and glasses. That's fine, I can take it then.

Veslemøy and Sven. Isn't that a great little peasant antique? Is that your hat? It's probably something to have flowers in. It hung on the wall, and then you had salt in there. Desired things. People pay NOK 500-600 for one like that.

You will be given a task instead. So far into October, and then you've got your summer dress on. If I say Doris von Kappelhoff, what do you think? I only know one Doris, and that's Doris Day. Was it her? Doris von Kappelhoff.

Did you have pictures of her? Not me, but many others. She was a huge star in the 50s and a little into the 60s. Then she was a big star in the US and elsewhere. She was actually going to be a dancer. She and her mother traveled from Seattle to Los Angeles to take dance lessons.

Then the car was hit by a train, so Doris Day destroyed her foot. So she became a singer instead. Never a dancer. But she played in many films. She sang very well. 39 films, but she was very good at singing. It is as an actress that she became best known.

We're going to a song, and you can probably guess which one. By Doris Day? What am I thinking then? Que sera, sera? Then maybe you know the movie too? No, I can't know everything. "The Man Who Knew Too Much."

There was also a Norwegian version. It was Nora Brockstedt who sang it then. That was in 1956, the same year it became famous in the United States. The person who wrote it was Arne Bendiksen.

Now we will look at Dutch hand painted tiles. We are with the siblings Hans Jacob Haga and Inger Johanne Rygh. Now I have to admit at the outset that I initially referred to this as cackles. But that is wrong. Tiles were made into stoves.

Here is a tile, it is hollow on the back to preserve the heat. While you collect Dutch tiles. But then I have to ask what Dutch tiles are. They were made as early as the 17th century in Holland. Hand-painted tiles that were used for decoration on the walls.

But they also had an educational function. Biblical motifs, elephants, which were not seen in Holland. It was the television of the time that they watched in the evening. Show me some that they sat and discussed. We have some that just showed daily life.

A hunter, a trader, etc. Then there are more baroque fantasies: An angel jumping rope. It's a biblical motif, I thought everyone had it. Not very biblical with an angel jumping rope.

column2:
Vel møtt. I kveld skal vi til Halden til Atle Staal, som samler på symaskiner. Han har et brukbart utvalg. Ellers skal du få se på antikviteter, denne blant annet. Først skal vi sette i gang Gerd og Frode. Du skjærer brød, Gerd.

Er det smørbrød? Nei, brødpudding. Vi skal lage to, en av grovt brød og en av fint. Den fine, til søndags, skal Frode lage. En hverdagspudding og en søndagspudding. Til søndagspuddingen bruker vi hvitt brød.

Men det er jo dessert, det hadde de vel ikke i gamle dager. Det var en viktig del av måltidet. Alltid suppe og hovedrett eller hovedrett og dessert. Man brukte mer dessert før enn nå. Hva gjør du nå? Jeg holder på med "smeten".

"Smeten" igjen. Det må da være et annet ord for det? En kan jo kalle det røre, men jeg holder på "smeten". Du kaller jo saus også for det. Eller kakedeig. Den består av ...? Egg, sukker og melk sammenpiska.

Du skal få oppskrifta senere. Nå skal vi legge brødet i bløt i en halv time. Dette skal du få av meg til hverdagsbrødene dine. Nå skal det trekke inn i brødet, så det blir saftig og godt.

Da går vi og ser på antikviteter imens, denne blant annet. Ellen, den kunne du nok ha tenkt deg. Flotte greier. Det er ei vestlandstine. Det ser ut som viksdalsmaling, det er vanligvis på oransje bunn.

Inni ser vi at det er sponarbeid. En eneste sponskive.

Den er sveipet og sydd sammen med bjørketeger. De gjorde seg flid i gamle dager. Når en setter på lokket, knepper det fint på plass. Da kan en ha med seg mat i den. Hvis en skulle ut på slåtteteigen, kunne en bruke denne.

Kan du se hvor gammel den er? Rundt århundreskiftet. Har man en sånn en, kan en regne med at den er verdt ...? Jeg har den til salgs i butikken, og den koster ...? Da koster den 2300? Litt mer, 2900. Men kan prutes ned til 2500?

Jeg ser du har satt fra noen ... Umiddelbart ville jeg sagt jenteting, men dette er noe som gutter brukte i gamle dager. Ikke helt riktig. Ei fransk dronning hadde konstant hodepine. Hun merket at når hun snuste, ble hodepinen bedre. Dette spredde seg i de høyere kretser på hoffene i Europa.

Det ble et statussymbol. På 1700-tallet var dette eneste tobakksnytelse i de høyere lag. Snuste jentene på 1700-tallet? Ja, det var vanlig. Snusen er tørkede tobakksblad tilsatt aromatiske stoffer. Så ble de knust eller raspet opp, og så snuste de det inn.

De nyste og styrte noe voldsomt. Det må ha vært pulver der. Det er altså en eksklusiv snusdåse. Ja, den er fra Sørlandet fra rundt 1780. Den kalles diskosflaske, laget i Larvik. Kanskje en bonde har skåret den ut i valbjørk. Så hadde han gått til en sølvsmed og fått satt sølv på den.

For ei sånn flaske må en betale rundt 8000 kroner for. Det er ettertraktet samlerobjekt. Innhult og med sølv. Den er fantastisk laget, for den kan bare hules inn fra midten. Det som jeg vil kalle puslearbeid.

1700-tallet var snusens århundre. Det vil jeg kalle et smykkeskrin. Det er så vakkert som et smykke. Snusdåse i sølv. Den er laget på Strømsand ved Drammen av Nils Bøck. I ca. 1780.

Motivet er i typisk rokokko med s-former, c-former, litt muslinger og blomster flettet inn i et overdådig mønster. Muslingform på hele dåsen. Motivet er bibelsk. Kain og Abel, broderdrapet. De skulle ofre markens grøde, og da oppdaget Kain

at Abels bål røyk mye bedre, så han ble sjalu og drepte broren. Mønstret er nok kjøpt fra utlandet, for mange gullsmeder har brukt det samme motivet. Og dette er en eksklusiv dåse? 10 000-15 000. Inni er den er fint forgylt.

De skulle være fine med hengsler, for en skulle kneppe den elegant opp med ei hånd. Du må trene ei stund. Forgylt inni for at ikke snusen skulle tære på sølvet. Hoffet gav ofte slike gaver til trofaste tjenere.

Det var bedre at de gav dem gaver enn penger direkte. Men hvis de trengte det, kunne de lett omsettes i mynt, for mange samlet da også. Jeg har ikke råd til den, men her ... Den er også fin, men det er ikke sølv. Jeg greide det nesten. Den er også nydelig, og samtidig.

Skåret av tre og rokokkomotiv på den også, med rocailler. Knekken er kanskje regence, altså litt tidligere. 10 000-15 000 for den i sølv. Litt mindre for den, da. Skal vi si 8000-10 000? Ja. Det ligger en til her, men nå er det så dyrt her at ...

Det er ikke gull? Nei, det er en bonderokokko. Den er i messing. Den har mistet formen, men motivet er i rokokko. Den er fra ca. 1819. Det motivet kan en se igjen på rosemaling og bunadsvanter. De ble strikket, og samme motivet brodert oppå.

Verdt ca. 3000 kroner. Det er jo overkommelig. Her er et bilde av de damene når de snuste. En forfatter skrev på 1700-tallet: "Hvorfor kvinner skal bruke snus." Det er langt, så jeg har komprimert det. "En god anledning til nytt bekjentskap er å by på en pris."

"Disse nydelige, svake, tankeløse vesener kan da lovprise snusen." "Hvor man får kjøpt de beste sorter etc." "Det gis også en glimrende anledning" "til å vise sine smukke hender og la diamantringene briljere." I gamle dager kjøpte altså guttene snus til jentene sine. I dag må vi kjøpe både roser, gull, diamanter ...

De hadde diamanter da også. Det var gutteting og litt jenteting. Men her er det jenteting. Er ikke den nydelig? Jo, den er veldig fin. Vi er nå over på bunader, er det dokkebunader?

Det er en dåpslue. Den er fra 1830. Med den dusken bak her ser det ut som den er fra Nepal, men den er fra Hålandsdalen. Du mener vel ikke at moten vandret fra Nepal? Nei, men den ser litt sånn ut. Ei dåpslue, altså.

Dette er også ettertraktede ting. Ut fra snusdåsene er den vel verdt noen tusen, denne også. Jeg betalte mye for den på en auksjon i Hålandsdalen. Jeg ville solgt den for 2000 kroner. Ikke mer? Det var ikke så ille.

Hvis du ikke skal si mer om den, har jeg lyst til å ta lua av. Du har satt den oppå noe artig. Det var i mangel av noe annet. Dette er noe til å stappe poteter med. Men den også er gammel og god. Du skal få 30 kroner for den.

Det får du ta opp med Gerd etterpå, for det er hennes. Hun er lett å handle med, så jeg skal snakke med henne. Jeg må vise en til. Det er typisk Hardanger med de broderte perlene. Jeg vet ikke helt hvor gammel den er, men et stykke uti forrige årh. Den skulle vært litt restaurert. Den vil jeg ha 1500 kroner for.

Og vi snakker fortsatt om dåpsluer? Ja, det ser en på størrelsen. Hvis noen har lyst til å lese om dette, har Huitfeldts forlag ei lita bok om det. Der kan en lære om dåpsdrakter. Ja, og med masse fine bilder. Nå har jeg lyst til å vise deg ei bok vi har fått fra Aksel Økselsrud.

Han har faktisk funnet opp denne boka, og den er fin. Den heter: "Tingene forteller." Du kan plukke ut de mest verdifulle tingene du har. Det står ei grei bruksanvisning her. Så setter du et bilde av tingen her, og så kan du skrive hva det dreier seg om.

Det er jo kjekt for arvinger. Skrive historien om tingen, så den ikke går i glemmeboka. Så er det forsikringsaspektet. Hvis man har verdifulle ting, og er så uheldig at det blir stjålet, kan en legge boka i en bankboks, og den viser hva du har.

Dette er en fin oppfinnelse. Jeg vet ikke om den fins i bokhandelen, men får du ikke tak i den, så gjør du som med oppskriftene. Send oss en frankert svarkonvolutt, så skal vi sende deg adressa der du kan få tak i denne boka. Vi sender med oppskrifter også, hvis du vil.

Jeg avbrøt deg visst. Vi skal vel videre på jentetingene. Er det dåpskjole? Et så lite hode kan vel ikke ha denne kjempekroppen. Dåpskjoler skal jo være store. Men ikke så brede skuldrer. Er det en selskapskjole? Ja, en silkekjole fra tidlig på århundret, som ei jente i 2-3-årsalderen har hatt.

Dette er ting som folk er på jakt etter. Det er jo så skjørt at en kan ikke bruke det. Men det er jo nydelig å bare ha den til pynt. Henge den på veggen, ramme den inn, eller ta den fram av og til. Godt gjort at de tok vare på dette. I dag kaster vi jo gamle klær eller gir dem bort. Mener du at vi bør ta vare på slike flotte kjoler?

Ja, klærne på 70-tallet er jo kommet tilbake nå. Hadde jeg gjemt på mine fra den gang, ville mange hatt dem nå. Men vi må ha store hus da. Det er det. Du sa ikke hva den er verdt? 800-900 kroner. Vi skal se på en annen fin kjole.

Veslemøy, så flott du var i kveld. Nå har vi satt Gerd og Frode i gang med brødpudding. Jeg nevnte i stad at guttene gav roser til jentene. Og nå skal det blir brød og roser. Du fant en fin overgang, nå. De fikk ikke mye brød og roser, dem vi skal synge om.

Vi skal tilbake til den industrielle revolusjon. Man fikk behov for kvinnelig arbeidskraft på fabrikkene. Da var det ofte så som så med forholdene for kvinnene. Sikkert også for menn. Bjørnson var jo også med og støttet dem. Det var på fystikkfabrikkene på Østlandet.

Bryn og Grønvold, het de. Der var det forferdelige forhold. Det var små jenter, noen under 12 år. Arbeidsdagen kunne være 12-13 timer. De fikk 10 kroner i uka, ofte mindre. Det er noe annet enn de som streiket i vår.
column3:
Well met. Tonight we are going to Halden to Atle Staal, who collects sewing machines. He has a useful selection. Otherwise, you will get to see antiques, this one among others. First we will start Gerd and Frode. You cut bread, Gerd.

Is it sandwiches? No, bread pudding. We will make two, one from coarse bread and one from fine. Frode will make the nice one, for Sunday. An everyday pudding and a Sunday pudding. For the Sunday pudding, we use white bread.

But it's dessert, I guess they didn't have that in the old days. It was an important part of the meal. Always soup and main course or main course and dessert. People used more dessert before than now. What are you doing now? I'm doing the "batter".

"The batter" again. There must be another word for it then? You can call it batter, but I stick to "batter". You also call it sauce. Or cookie dough. It consists of ...? Whisk eggs, sugar and milk together.

You will receive the recipe later. Now let the bread soak for half an hour. You will get this from me for your everyday bread. Now it should soak into the bread, so it will be juicy and good.

Then we go and look at antiques in the meantime, this one among others. Ellen, you could have thought that. Great stuff. It's a western style. It looks like viksdal paint, it is usually on an orange base.

Inside we see that there is chip work. A single spon disc.

It is swept and sewn together with birch battens. They were diligent in the old days. When you put the lid on, it clicks nicely into place. Then you can take food with you in it. If you were to go out on the lawn, you could use this.

Can you tell how old it is? Around the turn of the century. If you have one like that, can you count on it being worth ...? I have it for sale in the store and it costs ...? So it costs 2300? A little more, 2900. But can it be bargained down to 2500?

I see you have set some... Immediately I would say girl stuff, but this is something that guys used in the old days. Not quite right. A French queen had constant headaches. She noticed that when she sniffed, her headache got better. This spread in the higher circles of the courts in Europe.

It became a status symbol. In the 18th century, this was the only tobacco pleasure in the upper classes. Did girls snuff in the 18th century? Yes, it was common. Snuff is dried tobacco leaves with added aromatic substances. Then they were crushed or grated, and then they sniffed it in.

They sneezed and steered something violent. There must have been powder there. It is therefore an exclusive snuff box. Yes, it is from Southern Norway from around 1780. It is called a disco bottle, made in Larvik. Perhaps a farmer carved it out of walbirch. Then he had gone to a silversmith and had silver put on it.

For such a bottle you have to pay around NOK 8,000. It is a sought-after collector's item. Hollow and with silver. It is wonderfully made, because it can only be hollowed in from the middle. What I would call puzzle work.

The 18th century was the century of snuff. I would call that a jewelry box. It is as beautiful as a piece of jewelry. Snuff box in silver. It was made at Strømsand near Drammen by Nils Bøck. For about. 1780.

The motif is in typical rococo with s-shapes, c-shapes, some shells and flowers woven into a sumptuous pattern. Mussel shape on the entire tin. The motif is biblical. Cain and Abel, fratricide. They were to sacrifice the produce of the field, and then Cain discovered

that Abel's fire smoked much better, so he became jealous and killed his brother. The pattern was probably bought from abroad, because many jewelers have used the same motif. And this is an exclusive tin? 10,000-15,000. Inside it is nicely gilded.

They should be nice with hinges, because one would have to unbutton them elegantly with one hand. You have to train for a while. Gilded inside so that the snuff would not corrode the silver. The court often gave such gifts to faithful servants.

It was better that they gave them gifts than money directly. But if they needed to, they could easily be converted into coins, too many collected then too. I can't afford it, but here... It's also nice, but it's not silver. I almost made it. It is also beautiful, and at the same time.

Carved from wood and rococo motif on it too, with rocailles. The problem is perhaps the Regency, i.e. a little earlier. 10,000-15,000 for the one in silver. A little less for that one, then. Should we say 8,000-10,000? Yes. There is another one here, but now it is so expensive here that...

It's not gold? No, it's a peasant rococo. It is in brass. It has lost its shape, but the motif is in Rococo. It is from approx. 1819. That motif can be seen again on rose paint and bunad mittens. They were knitted, and the same motif embroidered on top.

Worth approx. NOK 3,000. It is manageable. Here is a picture of those ladies when they sniffed. A writer wrote in the 18th century: "Why women should use snuff." It's long, so I've condensed it. "A good opportunity to make new acquaintances is to offer a price."

"These lovely, weak, thoughtless beings can then praise snuff." "Where you can buy the best varieties etc." "It also provides an excellent opportunity" "to show off your beautiful hands and let your diamond rings shine." In the old days, boys bought snuff for their girls. Today we have to buy both roses, gold, diamonds...

They had diamonds then too. There were boy things and some girl things. But here it's girl stuff. Isn't it beautiful? Yes, it is very nice. We're now on bunades, are they dock bunades?

It's a christening hat. It is from 1830. With that tassel at the back here, it looks like it is from Nepal, but it is from Hålandsdalen. You don't mean that the fashion migrated from Nepal, do you? No, but it looks a bit like that. A christening hat, that is.

These are also desirable things. Based on the snuff tins, it is well worth a few thousand, this one too. I paid a lot for it at an auction in Hålandsdalen. I would sell it for NOK 2,000. No more? It wasn't that bad.

If you're not going to say more about it, I'd like to take my hat off. You have put it on top of something funny. It was for lack of anything else. This is something to stuff potatoes with. But it is also old and good. You will receive NOK 30 for it.

You can take that up with Gerd afterwards, because it's hers. She's easy to deal with, so I'll talk to her. I have to show one more. It is typical Hardanger with the embroidered pearls. I don't know exactly how old it is, but somewhere in the last century. It should have been slightly restored. I want NOK 1,500 for it.

And we're still talking about christening caps? Yes, it depends on the size. If anyone wants to read about this, Huitfeldt's publishing house has a small book about it. There you can learn about christening suits. Yes, and with lots of nice pictures. Now I would like to show you a book we have received from Aksel Økselsrud.

He actually invented this book, and it's great. It is called: "The things tell." You can pick out the most valuable things you have. There is a good user manual here. Then you put a picture of the thing here, and then you can write what it is about.

It's nice for heirs. Write the story of the thing, so it does not go into oblivion. Then there is the insurance aspect. If you have valuable things, and are unlucky enough to have them stolen, you can put the book in a safety deposit box, and it shows what you have.

This is a great invention. I don't know if it is available in the bookstore, but if you can't get hold of it, then do as with the recipes. Send us a stamped reply envelope and we will send you the address where you can get hold of this book. We will send with recipes too, if you want.

I must have interrupted you. I guess we'll move on to the girl stuff. Is it a christening gown? Such a small head can't possibly have this huge body. Christening dresses must be big. But not such broad shoulders. Is it a party dress? Yes, a silk dress from the beginning of the century, worn by a girl aged 2-3.

These are things that people are looking for. It is so fragile that one cannot use it. But it's lovely to just have it for decoration. Hang it on the wall, frame it, or take it out occasionally. Well done that they took care of this. Today, we throw away old clothes or give them away. Do you think we should take care of such beautiful dresses?

Yes, the clothes of the 70s are back now. If I had kept mine from then, many would have them now. But we must have big houses then. That's it. You didn't say what it's worth? NOK 800-900. We are going to look at another nice dress.

Veslemøy, how wonderful you were tonight. Now we have put Gerd and Frode to work on bread pudding. I mentioned that the boys gave roses to the girls. And now it will be bread and roses. You found a nice transition, now. They didn't get much bread and roses, the ones we're going to sing about.

We are going back to the industrial revolution. There was a need for female labor in the factories. Then it was often so-so with the conditions for the women. Certainly also for men. After all, Bjørnson was also there to support them. It was at the physics factories in Eastern Norway.

Bryn and Grønvold, they were called. There were terrible conditions. There were little girls, some under the age of 12. The working day could be 12-13 hours. They received NOK 10 a week, often less. It is something different from those who went on strike this spring.

column2:
Vi fordømmer jo barnearbeid i dag, men vi har ikke vært bedre selv heller. Nei, det er jo bare litt over 100 år siden. Det verste var at fosforet de jobbet med, gnagde seg gjennom tennene og inn i beinmargen, så enkelte av jentene ble deformerte i ansiktet. Da gikk de til streik.

Kom de for seint på jobb, måtte de jobbe til midnatt for å gjøre bot. Det var tider. Nå skal det handle om brød og roser. Visa handler om streik og ble laget i 1912 i USA. Tekstilarbeiderne i Massachusetts gikk til streik. Den er oversatt til norsk, og er av de mest kjente streikekvisene:

"Brød og roser". Kom igjen.

Da skal vi se hvordan det går med brødet. Har Gerd trua med fagforening? Det er vel heller omvendt. Nå har brødet ligget i bløt en halv time i det du kaller "smeten".

Hva skjer så? Vi legger det i smurt, ildfast form. Nå skal brødpuddingen lages. Ja, jeg legger loffen slik. Så smører jeg et lag med eplesyltetøy på. Man bør bruke epler for å støtte bøndene i Hardanger.

Ekte gravenstein. Dette er altså søndagspuddingen. Jeg lager hverdagspuddingen. Jeg slår også røre over brødet. Tar det godt utover. I gamle dager hadde man kanskje ikke så mye å fylle på med her.

Da strødde de litt revet sitronskall eller presset sitron på det. Strødde på noen rosiner kanskje. Selv om det var hverdagspudding? Ja. Ja, men vi skal bruke rabarbrasyltetøyet vi laget tidlig i høst. Det skal være et papir oppå her, som var dynket i konjakk.

Så heller jeg det på, og mer brød oppå. Og du legger på gravenstein fra Hardanger. Legg på eplebåter eller skiver. Det skal vel være fint, dette. En kan strø på kanel hvis en vil. Nei, ikke kanel. Liker du ikke kanel? Nei. Det er smak og behag, da kan en bruke andre krydder som passer.

Hvitløk? Det liker du, ja. Så ei skive til oppå? Ja, nå skal vi legge på lokket. Det blir jo en ganske kraftig dessert. Dette var en dessert en hadde etter en kanskje tynn middag. Hvis man hadde hatt rester, laget man en brøddessert til.

Samtidig fikk en jo brukt opp gammelt brød. Jeg har alltid sett på deg som ei god, gammeldags husmor, som brukte opp alt. Men så la jeg merke til at du skar bort skorpene. Jeg var sikker på at de skulle oppi her.

Når denne er ferdig, bruker jeg ettervarmen i stekovnen. Da tørker dette og blir fint griljeringsmel når det blir knust. Det brukte de ikke i gamle dager. Jo visst.

Jeg har litt av "smeten" igjen og slår bare på, bruker alt. Hva skal skje med denne brødpuddingen? Den skal inn i ovnen, stekes i vannbad i 1 time på 200 grader.

Da får vi smake. Vi reiser til Halden i mellomtida. Hjem til Atle Staal. Her er det symaskiner for alle pengene. Hva er det som er så gjevt med symaskiner?

De er dekorative. Utviklingen av dem, fra den spede begynnelsen og framover. Når kom den første symaskina? Det var et forsøk i 1755 av en ved navn Weissenthal.

Jeg trodde det var Singer. Nei, han var 100 år senere ute. Den du har satt fram her, er den eldste du har. Ja, det er et ukjent merke, men mest sannsynlig er den produsert i Tyskland 1850-60.

Er den så ny? Da er det ca. 100 år du ikke har symaskiner fra. Ja, jeg mangler det i samlinga mi, men det er vanskelig å få tak i. Denne er ganske fin som antikvitet. Alt fungerer jo helt som det skal. Ja, den kan en sy på.

Hvor mye skal du ha for den? Vanskelig å sette pris, men skulle jeg finne på å selge den, vil jeg ikke gå under 2000. Jeg syns ikke det var så ille. Har det vært noe utvikling her? Ja, på skyttelen, altså undertråden.

På den som står der, tilsvarer én gang rundt på sveiva, ett sting. Når en kommer over på den, er det to sting. Den er litt mer avansert. Fra hvilket årstall? Den stammer fra en fabrikk som eksisterte fra 1879-84. Dette blir veldig detaljert.

Du vet jo alt på datoen nesten. Når det gjelder Singer, er det lett å få greie på årstall. Men når det gjelder andre merker, er det ikke ført opp mye før 1850. Man hadde ikke kartotekført serienummer. Er det en del av interessen din?

Ikke bare tingen, men industrihistorien bak? Industrihistorien og utviklingen av hele konseptet symaskin. Du snakket om utseende, dette er jo attraktive antikviteter. Når man går på auksjon eller loppemarked ser en ofte de flotte ...

De er jo dekorativt og fint utsmykket. Ja, på den tiden da de kom, var det eksempelvis av denne typen. Jeg har sett på den. De stod framme, og det var jo et statussymbol å ha symaskiner. Da ble utsmykningen deretter.

Den stod på et bord, som et møbel, et statussymbol. På slutten av 1800-tallet, da den kom, kostet den nok mye mer enn en maskin gjør i dag. Så ikke alle hadde råd til det? Nei.

Jeg spurte deg om den eldste, og du antydet 2000. Hvis jeg ber tynt om å få kjøpe den? Jeg har fått bud på 5000, men hadde ikke hjerte til å la den gå. Det står noen fine bak ryggen min. Disse perlemorgreiene er innfelt, så dette må være verdifulle ting.

Tja ... Akkurat dem du har der, er tyskproduserte. Muligens fra samme firma, eller to fabrikker som lå vegg i vegg. I Tyskland produserte man den typen maskiner. Det er en klonet modell som heter Singer 12.

Det er tynne lag med perlemor, bare lagt inn i lakken. Denne er vel også litt spesiell. Det er en Husqvarna. Men den heter Singer. For å gjøre folk forvirra? De prøvde vel å selge på navnet Singer da den kom. Husqvarna Singer Salong.

Maskinene dine er veldig fine. Du pusser og steller og reparerer dem. Ja, en må alltid ha reservedeler, for en får ikke kjøpt nye til slike gamle maskiner i dag. Kommer jeg over "fillete" maskiner, er de også velkomne hit, for det kan være deler som jeg trenger.

Er det vanskelig å få tak i dem? Jeg merker at det blir verre. Det virker som folk har oppdaget at det er fint å ha ei slik stående. På ny er det kanskje status. Ja. Kjøper du alt du kommer over?

Du må jo bygge ut hvis du fortsetter i dette tempoet. Nei, nå har jeg stagnert en del. Jeg har gått mer over til å skaffe meg litteratur og reklamemateriell. Jeg vil lese mer om firmaer og utviklingen. Du ordner vel din egen garderobe, og sender ikke noe til skredderen?

Det lar jeg kona ta seg av, for jeg kan ikke sy. Takk for oss, Atle Staal. Takk skal dere ha. Nå kan det ikke bli en annen sang enn: Symaskin-skin-skin, syma-ma-ma-ma-maskin ... Hver gang du har sjansen, begynner du å synge. Er det den? Ikke helt.

Du som er så glad i skog og mark. Særlig over skoggrensa. Du vet hva lyktemenn er. Jeg har hørt om Lyktemannen. Du har ikke sett små, blå flammer som hopper bortover myra? Man mente det var spedbarn som ikke ble døpt som gikk igjen.

Men det er gasser i myra som lyser. Men det var Lyktemannen vi skulle fram til. Frimann Clasen, som skrev over 10 000 sanger. Det er en anselig mengde. Han begynte i Kringkastningen i 1925, da det startet opp.

Da fikk han sitt eget radioprogram med ukerevyer. Han var den tidligste, lenge før våre ukerevyer. Han var en stor humorist. Er dette ei humoristisk vise eller ei reklamevise? Da må det være reklame for Vinmonopolet. Det må en vel være forsiktig med. Ja.

Får håpe Olsen finner fram til slutt, og jeg håper brødpuddingen er ferdig. Vi skal se. Hva skal vi smake på først? Vi går hit til Gerds hverdagspudding. Denne ser lekker ut. La meg få prøve. Det skal du få. Den er vel ikke for varm? Nei da.

Vi har kjølt den av litt før du kom. Denne skal også avkjøles. Skal jeg ha rød saus? Ja. Det er vanlig, og den kjenner de fleste til. Dette er altså hverdagspuddingen. Den ser god ut.

Litt varm var den. Inni er den vel fortsatt varm. Denne var jo mer enn god nok til å ha om søndagen også. Nå skal vi prøve søndagspuddingen. Vi skal flambere den. Ikke fortell meg at de flamberte i gamle dager.

Å flambere er ikke noe problem, for alkoholen brenner opp. Det er for å sette en egen smak på den. Det ligger jo igjen litt. Jeg fikk rød saus på av Gerd. Det skal du få av meg også.

Kjenner jeg forskjell? Ja, det tror jeg sikkert. Nå ser jeg at det er søndag her. Du verden, la meg få smake. Kjempegodt. Her skal du også få oppskrifta.

Skikkelig godt var det. Frode sa noe viktig til meg. Angående eplebåtene som Frode la ned i midten. Det var ikke rå epler. Nei, lettkokte i sukkerlake. Fikk du ikke med deg oppskrifta, finner du den på tekst-tv s. 509. Eller send en frankert svarkonvolutt, så får du oppskriftene.

Så ses vi igjen om 14 dager. Jeg må ha mer av den.
column3:
We condemn child labor today, but we haven't been any better ourselves either. No, it was just over 100 years ago. The worst part was that the phosphorus they were working with gnawed through the teeth and into the bone marrow, so some of the girls were deformed in the face. Then they went on strike.

If they were late for work, they had to work until midnight to make up for it. There were times. Now it will be about bread and roses. Visa is about strikes and was created in 1912 in the USA. The textile workers in Massachusetts went on strike. It has been translated into Norwegian, and is one of the most famous strike jokes:

"Bread and Roses". Come on.

Then we'll see how the bread goes. Does Gerd believe in a trade union? It's probably the other way around. Now the bread has been soaking for half an hour in what you call "the batter".

What happens then? We put it in a greased, refractory form. Now the bread pudding must be made. Yes, I put the loaf like that. Then I spread a layer of applesauce on it. Apples should be used to support the farmers in Hardanger.

Real tombstone. So this is the Sunday pudding. I make the everyday pudding. I also put batter over the bread. Take it well beyond. In the old days, you probably didn't have much to fill up here.

Then they sprinkled some grated lemon peel or squeezed lemon on it. Sprinkled on some raisins perhaps. Even if it was everyday pudding? Yes. Yes, but we will use the rhubarb jam we made early this autumn. There should be a piece of paper on top here, which was soaked in brandy.

Then I pour it on, and more bread on top. And you put on gravestone from Hardanger. Add apple wedges or slices. It must be nice, this. You can sprinkle on cinnamon if you like. No, not cinnamon. Don't like cinnamon? No. It is a matter of taste and preference, then you can use other spices that suit.

Garlic? You like that, yes. So another slice on top? Yes, now we will put the lid on. It will be quite a powerful dessert. This was a dessert you had after a perhaps thin dinner. If you had leftovers, you made another bread dessert.

At the same time, you used up stale bread. I have always seen you as a good, old-fashioned housewife, who used up everything. But then I noticed you cut away the crusts. I was sure they were going up here.

When this is finished, I use the afterheat in the oven. This then dries and becomes fine grilling flour when crushed. They didn't use that in the old days. Of course.

I have some of the "batter" left and just turn on, use it all. What will happen to this bread pudding? It should go into the oven, be baked in a water bath for 1 hour at 200 degrees.

Then we get to taste. We travel to Halden in the meantime. Home to Atle Staal. Here there are sewing machines for every price. What is so special about sewing machines?

They are decorative. Their development, from the very beginning onwards. When did the first sewing machine come out? There was an attempt in 1755 by someone named Weissenthal.

I thought it was Singer. No, he was out 100 years later. The one you have presented here is the oldest you have. Yes, it is an unknown brand, but most likely it was produced in Germany 1850-60.

Is it that new? Then it is approx. 100 years since you didn't have sewing machines. Yes, I'm missing it in my collection, but it's hard to come by. This one is quite nice as an antique. Everything works exactly as it should. Yes, it can be sewn on.

How much do you want for it? Difficult to put a price on, but if I were to sell it, I wouldn't want to go below 2000. I don't think it was that bad. Has there been any development here? Yes, on the shuttle, i.e. the lower thread.

On the one standing there, one round of the crank corresponds to one stitch. When you come across it, there are two stitches. It is a bit more advanced. From which year? It originates from a factory that existed from 1879-84. This gets very detailed.

You know almost everything on the date. When it comes to Singer, it's easy to figure out the years. But as far as other brands are concerned, not much was recorded before 1850. Serial numbers were not recorded. Is that part of your interest?

Not just the thing, but the industrial history behind it? The industrial history and development of the entire sewing machine concept. You talked about appearance, these are attractive antiques. When you go to an auction or flea market, you often see the beautiful ...

They are decorative and nicely decorated. Yes, at the time when they came, it was for example of this type. I have looked at it. They stood at the front, and it was a status symbol to have sewing machines. Then the decoration was done accordingly.

It stood on a table, like a piece of furniture, a status symbol. At the end of the 19th century, when it arrived, it probably cost a lot more than a machine does today. So not everyone could afford it? No.

I asked you about the oldest one and you suggested 2000. If I ask thin to buy it? I got an offer of 5000, but didn't have the heart to let it go. There are some nice people behind my back. These mother-of-pearl things are inset, so these must be valuable things.

Well... Exactly the ones you have there are German-made. Possibly from the same company, or two factories that were next to each other. That type of machine was produced in Germany. It is a cloned model called the Singer 12.

There are thin layers of mother-of-pearl, just added to the varnish. This one is also a bit special. It's a Husqvarna. But it's called Singer. To confuse people? I guess they tried to sell on the Singer name when it came out. Husqvarna Singer Salon.

Your machines are very nice. You clean and groom and repair them. Yes, you must always have spare parts, because you cannot buy new ones for such old machines today. If I come across "ragged" machines, they are also welcome here, because there may be parts that I need.

Is it hard to get hold of them? I notice it's getting worse. It seems that people have discovered that it is nice to have such a portrait. Again, maybe it's status. Yes. Do you buy everything you come across?

You have to expand if you continue at this pace. No, now I have stagnated quite a bit. I have switched more to acquiring literature and advertising material. I want to read more about companies and developments. You organize your own wardrobe, and don't send anything to the tailor?

I'll let my wife take care of that, because I can't sew. Thank you for us, Atle Staal. Thank you. Now there can be no other song than: Sewing machine-skin-skin, sewing-ma-ma-ma-machine ... Every time you have the chance, you start singing. Is that it? Not completely.

You who are so fond of forests and fields. Especially above the forest border. You know what lantern men are. I've heard of the Lantern Man. You haven't seen small, blue flames jumping across the marsh? It was believed that it was infants who were not baptized who went again.

But there are gases in the marsh that glow. But it was the Lantern Man we were going to get to. Frimann Clasen, who wrote over 10,000 songs. That is a considerable amount. He joined Kringkastningen in 1925, when it first started.

Then he got his own radio program with weekly reviews. He was the earliest, long before our weekly reviews. He was a great humorist. Is this a humorous show or an advertising show? Then there must be advertising for Vinmonopolet. You have to be careful with that. Yes.

Let's hope Olsen finds it in the end, and I hope the bread pudding is finished. We shall see. What shall we taste first? We go here for Gerd's everyday pudding. This one looks delicious. Let me try. You'll get that. It's not too hot, is it? No, then.

We cooled it down a bit before you came. This must also be cooled. Should I have red sauce? Yes. It is common, and most people are familiar with it. This is the everyday pudding. It looks good.

It was a bit warm. It's probably still warm inside. This was more than good enough to have on Sunday as well. Now we're going to try the Sunday pudding. We're going to flambé it. Don't tell me they flambéed in the old days.

Flaming is not a problem, because the alcohol burns up. It's to put your own flavor on it. There is still a bit left. I got red sauce on from Gerd. You will get that from me too.

Do I know the difference? Yes, I certainly think so. Now I see that it is Sunday here. You world, let me taste. Very good. You will also get the recipe here.

It was quite good. Frode said something important to me. Regarding the apple boats that Frode put down in the middle. It wasn't raw apples. No, lightly boiled in sugar brine. If you didn't get the recipe with you, you can find it on Teletext p. 509. Or send a stamped reply envelope and you'll get the recipes.

See you again in 14 days. I must have more of it.

column2:
Da får de veldig god smak. Dette var ting folk kunne oppbevare. Gulrøtter, saltet kjøtt, kålrabi, poteter og kål. Det var ting de hadde med seg på båten. Her skjærer vi gulrøttene i store biter. Kjøttet er seigest og trenger halvannen time før det blir mørt. De blir litt mer kokt enn til vanlig.

Kokt helt sund? Nei, de gjør ikke det. Få oppi resten. Svære kålrabibiter. Ca. 3 cm tykke. Du sier at det ikke er lapskaus, men når jeg ser det du skal ha oppi på slutten, så ...

Hva med fårikål? Nei, det er bare kål og får. En har ikke saltet kjøtt til fårikål, men ferskt kjøtt. Smaken kan bli noe lignende, men det er en helt annen rett. En blanding av lapskaus og fårikål. Vent til du får smake.

Det nærmeste du kommer, er "irish stew". Så må vi ha lokk på. Det er viktig at det kokes under lokk. Koke halvannen time og vann bare opp til kjøttet. Da må en vel fylle på, da? Nei, en skal ikke det. Det er jo derfor han har lokk på, så det ikke skal fordampe.

Så får du passe på, Gerd. Så skal det være kokte poteter til. Dem setter vi på de siste tre kvarterene. Potetene også oppi her? Alt i ei gryte. Dette har jeg lyst til å smake på. Kom, så skal vi se. Her står Ellen Ørnes. Du verden. Fint skap.

Får jeg tippe? Det er iallfall et kråskap. Det ser man på skapet. Så skal jeg imponere med å si at det er fra 1831, for det står her. Det er iallfall malt i 1831. Men det kan komme fra både Hallingdal, Telemark og Voss.

Er det fra Hardanger? Ja, du imponerer. Hvordan ser du det? Enn du? Jeg så det på malinga og rosene. Du har vært mye rundt der. Malingen er fra Hardanger fra 1831, men skapet er eldre. Når vi ser på alle de små fyllingene rundt omkring.

På listverket øverst ser vi eggstav. Denne kalles tannsnitt og barokktunge. Da kan vi anta at skapet er ganske mye eldre. Kanskje tidlig 1700-tall. Det er et koselig skap med spesielle søyler. Det er mye arbeid på et sånt skap,

men på 1700-tallet var det vanlig å ha sånt i stuene. I dag blir de sett på som voldsomme stasskap. Det var stasmøbler, da også. Rosemalere reiste rundt. Man måtte ha god råd for å unne seg sånne ting. Det var fint på den tida, som det er vakkert i dag også.

Skapet har jo levd i flere hundre år, og det kan det ennå gjøre. Dette er enormt ettertraktede ting. Folk er ville etter å få tak i dette. Men det er ikke for hvem som helst. Jeg byr 17 000. Det er nok bare tøys. Det er lov å prøve seg. Det skapet kan jeg nok ikke selge.

Men kommer man over et, må man i forretninger betale kr 50 000. Kanskje mer, det kommer an på hvilken stand det er i. Kommer dette på auksjon, og de 2-3 rette personene er der, så kan vel skapet havne over 100 000 kroner. Det er dine ord, Kjell. Det tror jeg.

Hva har du lagt fram her? En portiere. Ikke veggteppe? Nei, det har vært to stykker. Det er vevd på Ragna Breiviks vevskole i Bergen på 30-tallet. Jeg vet det, for jeg har lånt det av Gerd. En slektning av henne har vevd den.

I transparentvevinga ligger en del av renninga åpen, så lyset kommer igjennom. Det blir veldig vakkert når den henger i rommet. Er det en spesiell teknikk? Ei som het Frida Hansen, som var dyktig med tekstiler, tok patent på vevteknikken i 1897.

Så ingen andre fikk bruke den? Jo, men det var hennes patent. Hun var internasjonalt veldig anerkjent. Hun var nok den i nyere europeisk tekstilkunst som var dyktigst. Hun har ikke vevd dette, men hadde det dukket opp noe av henne, så ...

Det er sjeldent. Den skulle jeg gjerne ha kjøpt. Men hvis det dukker opp noe av Frida Hansen på en auksjon, og du byr privat, hvor langt strekker du deg? Jeg vet ikke. Det vil vise seg hvis det dukker opp noe.

Det er i hvert fall flotte ting. Kunsthåndverk av ypperste klasse. Vil du si noe mer om det? Fine farger. Så har vi funnet fram en navneduk. Navneduk har vi sett på for ett eller to år siden.

Du har forklart meg så mye at du må ta det en gang til. De ble vanlige på begynnelsen av 1700-tallet. Da helst i de øvre sosiale lag. For at kvinnene skulle bli et godt kjerringemne.

Så ungdommen satt og øvde seg? Ja, de skulle lære seg broderiteknikker, bokstaver. Så de kunne brodere navn på undertøy og lintøy. For dem som ikke hadde så god råd, var det like viktig å lære det, for de kunne kanskje tjene penger på det senere, hvis de var flinke.

Urner går mye igjen. På navnedukene ble det populært med minne om sine forfedre. Her står hun ved en grav. Så er det kanskje initialene til forfedre rundt omkring på duken. Denne er morsom. En liten hund som hopper rundt på to.

Denne er veldig fin. En mann kjøpte den på en auksjon. Han har betalt 4500 kroner for den. Det er ganske mye. En kan jo få en slik for 1000 kroner og oppover. Men denne har veldig bra kvalitet. Jeg spøkte litt i stad. Fortell hvordan du ser empirestilen her. Hvis vi sammenligner med noe annet. Vi legger vekk denne.

I forrige program viste vi fram masse snusdåser fra rokokkoen. Det er en usymmetrisk og overdådig stilart. Som reaksjon på den kom nyklassisismen. Da brukte de mye fra det gamle Hellas. Girlander, medaljong, og urne, som vi så på den andre.

Dette er et norsk arbeid av en veldig dyktig treskjærer. Sikkert en laugstreskjærer. Så er det Den norske løve på. Hva skal du ha for snusdåsa? Den er mye finere enn de forrige. Du må nok ut med 10 000 kroner, men dette er et strøkent eksemplar.

Så den rare løva som har rotet seg inn med den lange rumpa. Løva er det norskeste av alle dyr. Den er jo i riksvåpenet. Det er rart, for det er ikke så mange løver i Norge. Hva er denne løva? En liten snusdåse. Så interessert du er i snusdåsar, da. Du er vel ikke ... Få se.

Det er jo du som snuser. Det er for din del jeg har tatt dem med. Dette er vel ingen snusdåse. Jo. En fyller på snus under. Så tar en det ut her. Også laget av en dyktig treskjærer. Det ble solgt ei slik ei på auksjon for 4-5 år siden.

Da gikk den for 3000 kroner, og vi vet at det fins flere av dem. Den er kanskje laget av en i Kristiania. Veldig fine ting, men nå får det være nok snusdåser. Her ligger det også flotte ting. Ja, koselig å henge på kjøkkenveggen. Ei gammel kaffekvern.

Nykvernet kaffe er jo bedre enn den en kjøper i poser. Kan du tidfeste ei slik kaffekvern? 20-30-tallet. På den tida var det også populært med spiserisett. Krukker der det stod mel, farin - krydderbokser og sånt. Gjerne i sett, og med samme dekoren på disse også.

Ettertraktede ting, dette også. Ja, de er populære. 1200-1500 kroner. Vi sier 1000, da. Skal du ha den? Ja. Du har kjøpt mye etter hvert. Her står det et gammelt ferdaskrin. Dere har lært meg så mye. Frode sier "smeten" og du sier "skabbat".

Dette er litt "skabbat". Hvis du hadde vært 150 år, så ... Det er fare for det, men ser du at det er 150 år? Nei, men jeg kan anslå noe sånt. Det er mye jernbeslag rundt fordi de skulle tåle en støyt. De hadde det med på sjøen, på slede og hest og vogn.

Dette er restaurert litt, men ellers har det ikke hengt sammen. Det er en ganske grovbarket antikvitet som passer i en sjøbod eller ei kjellerstue. En gammel koffert. Du er ikke så begeistret for slikt. For grovt for stua. Men i en sjøbod eller på et passende sted, så.

1000 kroner? Det er ikke mitt. Men på en auksjon ble det kanskje både 1000 og 2000 kroner. Kommer de rette personene på auksjon, fyker det lett opp i 2000. Vi skal synge litt, men først har Veslemøy noe. Kom her, Veslemøy. Den har jeg lånt av moren min.

Jeg har lurt på hva det kan være. Vi holder en knapp på askebeger. Er du enig i at det er et flott askebeger i sølv, Ellen? Nei, vi hadde en maken hjemme. Den var på frokostbordet hvis vi hadde gjester. Da var det ei lita glasskål oppi. Det er ikke sølv.

Har du den? Nei, så den er ikke helt komplett. Vi brukte den til å ha fine smørkuler oppi. Men jeg vet ikke om det er det den er laget for. Det er jo praktisk, så ikke fluene kommer oppi. Den er fra 1904, står det. Har du kjøpt den? Nei, den er i familien.

Jeg skal ikke selge den heller. Den er fin, men når glasset er borte, er den ikke komplett. Det er typisk når hun skal kjøpe noe. Det er vel ikke noe problem å få ei glasskål til den. Jo, det er et problem, for den har en spesiell form. Slikt er alltid vanskelig å få tak i.

Uten glasskål, Ellen? 500-600 kroner maks. Vi skal ha den hjemme på hylla isteden. Den har affeksjonsverdi. Det er hyggelig med arv. Jeg har en sang som passer godt inn her. Riktig atmosfære.

En danske som het Erik Bøgh, levde på 1800-tallet. Han kom til Norge og fikk satt opp "vaudeville". Det var forløperen til revyen her i Norge. Om en peppersvenn som blir bedradd av sine elskerinner. Han har til slutt et helt museum med ting han fikk av elskerinnene. Det var ikke dumt.

Du får kroken her, og syng av hjertens lyst. Vær så god.

Nå er jeg spent, Gerd og Frode. Nå har dere kokt puspas her i hele kveld. Få se. Puspas. Det lukter godt. Du verden. Dette må jeg få lov å smake på. Mens de lager en porsjon puspas til meg, skal du få oppskrifta.

Jeg tror den er veldig enkel.
column3:
Then they get a very good taste. These were things people could keep. Carrots, salted meat, kohlrabi, potatoes and cabbage. It was stuff they brought with them on the boat. Here we cut the carrots into large pieces. The meat is tough and needs an hour and a half before it becomes tender. They will be slightly more cooked than usual.

Cooked completely healthy? No, they don't. Get the rest. Heavy pieces of kohlrabi. About. 3 cm thick. You say it's not stew, but when I see what you're going to put in at the end, so...

What about mutton cabbage? No, it's just cabbage and sheep. You don't have salted meat for mutton cabbage, but fresh meat. The taste may be similar, but it is a completely different dish. A mixture of stew and mutton cabbage. Wait until you taste.

The closest you get is "Irish stew". Then we have to put a lid on it. It is important that it is cooked under a lid. Boil for an hour and a half and water only up to the meat. Then you have to top it up, right? No, one shouldn't. That's why he has a lid on, so it doesn't evaporate.

Then you have to watch out, Gerd. Then there will be boiled potatoes. We put them in the last three quarters. The potatoes in here too? All in one pot. I want to taste this. Come, we'll see. Here is Ellen Ørnes. Oh my. Nice cabinet.

Can I guess? At least it's a hoot. You can see that in the cupboard. Then I will impress by saying that it is from 1831, because it says here. At least it was painted in 1831. But it could come from both Hallingdal, Telemark and Voss.

Is it from Hardanger? Yes, you impress. How do you see it? Than you? I saw it in the paint and the roses. You've been around a lot there. The paint is from Hardanger from 1831, but the cabinet is older. When we look at all the small fillings around.

On the molding at the top, we see egg staves. This is called tooth cut and baroque tongue. Then we can assume that the cabinet is quite a bit older. Perhaps early 18th century. It is a cozy cabinet with special columns. It's a lot of work on a cabinet like that,

but in the 18th century it was common to have such things in living rooms. Today, they are seen as fierce statecraft. It was state furniture, then too. Rose painters traveled around. You had to have good advice to indulge in such things. It was beautiful at the time, as it is beautiful today.

The cabinet has lived for hundreds of years, and it can still do so. These are hugely sought-after items. People are dying to get their hands on this. But it's not for just anyone. I offer 17,000. It's probably just bullshit. It is allowed to try. I probably can't sell that cabinet.

But if you come across one, you have to pay NOK 50,000 in shops. Maybe more, it depends on the condition it's in. If this comes up for auction, and the 2-3 right people are there, then the cabinet could end up over 100 NOK 000. Those are your words, Kjell. I think so.

What have you presented here? A porter. Not tapestry? No, there have been two pieces. It was woven at Ragna Breivik's weaving school in Bergen in the 1930s. I know, because I borrowed it from Gerd. A relative of hers has woven it.

In the transparent weave part of the warp is open, so the light comes through. It will be very beautiful when it hangs in the room. Is it a special technique? Someone called Frida Hansen, who was skilled with textiles, took out a patent for the weaving technique in 1897.

So no one else was allowed to use it? Yes, but it was her patent. She was very internationally recognized. She was probably the most skilled in recent European textile art. She hasn't woven this, but had something of hers appeared, then...

It is rare. I would have liked to have bought it. But if something by Frida Hansen turns up at an auction, and you bid privately, how far do you go? I do not know. It will show if something comes up.

At least it's great stuff. Craftsmanship of the highest class. Would you like to say anything more about it? Nice colors. Then we came up with a name cloth. We looked at name cloth one or two years ago.

You have explained so much to me that you have to take it one more time. They became common in the early 18th century. Preferably in the upper social strata. So that the women would become a good old woman subject.

So the youth sat and practiced? Yes, they were to learn embroidery techniques, letters. So they could embroider names on underwear and linen. For those who were not so well off, it was just as important to learn it, because they might be able to make money from it later, if they were clever.

Urns go back a lot. Name cloths became popular with memories of one's ancestors. Here she is standing by a grave. Then there are perhaps the initials of ancestors all around the cloth. This one is funny. A small dog that jumps around on two feet.

This one is very nice. A man bought it at an auction. He has paid NOK 4,500 for it. That's quite a lot. You can get one like this for NOK 1,000 and up. But this one has very good quality. I joked around a bit. Tell us how you see the empire style here. If we compare with something else. We put this one away.

In the previous programme, we showed lots of snuff boxes from the Rococo period. It is an asymmetrical and opulent style. Neoclassicism came as a reaction to it. Then they used a lot from ancient Greece. Garland, medallion, and urn, which we saw in the other.

This is a Norwegian work by a very skilled woodcarver. Surely a guild woodcutter. Then there is The Norwegian Lion on. What should you have for the snuff box? It is much nicer than the previous ones. You will probably have to fork out NOK 10,000, but this is a polished copy.

Then the strange lion that has messed around with the long ass. The lion is the most Norwegian of all animals. It is in the national coat of arms. It's strange, because there aren't that many lions in Norway. What is this lion? A small snuff box. So interested are you in snuff tins, then. You're probably not ... Let's see.

You're the one sniffing. It is for your sake that I have brought them. This is no snuff box. Yes. One refills snuff underneath. Then you take it out here. Also made by a skilled wood carver. One like this was sold at auction 4-5 years ago.

Then it went for NOK 3,000, and we know that there are more of them. It may have been made by someone in Kristiania. Very nice things, but for now it will be enough snuff boxes. There are also great things here. Yes, nice to hang on the kitchen wall. An old coffee grinder.

Freshly ground coffee is better than the one you buy in bags. Can you date such a coffee grinder? 20-30s. At that time, dining sets were also popular. Jars that contained flour, brown sugar - spice boxes and the like. Preferably in sets, and with the same decor on these too.

Desirable things, this too. Yes, they are popular. NOK 1200-1500. We say 1000, then. Are you going to have it? Yes. You have bought a lot over time. There is an old travel box here. You have taught me so much. Frode says "smeten" and you say "skabbat".

This is a bit "scabby". If you had been 150 years, then ... There is a danger of that, but do you see that it is 150 years? No, but I can estimate something like that. There are a lot of iron fittings around because they had to withstand a shock. They had it on the lake, on sledges and horse and cart.

This has been restored a little, but otherwise it has not been connected. It is a rather coarse-grained antique that fits in a sea shed or a cellar room. An old suitcase. You're not too excited about that. Too rough for the living room. But in a sea shed or in a suitable place, so.

NOK 1000? It's not mine. But at an auction it was perhaps both NOK 1,000 and 2,000. If the right people come to auction, it will easily rise to 2000. We will sing a bit, but first Veslemøy has something. Come here, Veslemøy. I borrowed it from my mother.

I've been wondering what it could be. We keep a button on the ashtray. Do you agree that it's a great silver ashtray, Ellen? No, we had a mate at home. It was on the breakfast table if we had guests. Then there was a small glass bowl inside. It's not silver.

Do you have it? No, so it is not quite complete. We used it to put nice balls of butter in it. But I don't know if that's what it's made for. It's practical, so the flies don't get in. It is from 1904, it says. Have you bought it? No, it's in the family.
