Say something in English. What does that mean? "Hey whats up?" Is that what you said?

My grandfather lived here. And father lived here when he was in Georgetown. Yes. He lived with my grandfather. Who lives here now? My brother lives here. Did your brother buy it? No, it still belongs to the family. My house!

Hello. My name is Yasmin.

So this is where they lived? And this was your grandfather's bedroom. Can I have a look?

When my father was here, where did he live? On the first or second floor? On the second floor. Up here, yes. Okay.

Can I see the kitchen? Yes.

Your grandfather liked to give gifts. Many gifts. He gave gifts to all the ladies at work at Gafur. It is nice. Was he a charmer? Yes. So he was the one my dad got it from? Good to know. Why didn't I get any of it? Yes. He was fond of ladies.

A ladies' man, yes. I have heard that, yes. So lovely. It's the Caribbean colors. Gorgeous.

It is nice.

Who won the match? Brazil. Are you all rooting for Brazil? Yes, we are Brazilians. They are our neighbors.

Pardon? Do you have cassava? Yes, here. This? No, the next one. This? And what exactly is it? A root fruit.

Very good. Different from potato chips. But quite salty and crunchy. It is local food and local tradition. People support it and buy it. How much does a bag like that cost? 100 dollars. American dollar? No. Guyanese dollar. How much is it in US dollars?

50 cents.

My great grandfather came to Guyana from India in 1866. How long was the journey? It took about three months from Calcutta to Highbury. Three months. And they sailed around South Africa. Yes. They sailed across the Atlantic and entered the Berbice River, where we are now.

How would you describe the journey from India to Guyana at that time? It was quite a tough journey. It depended on wind direction and wind strength. So it was quite a long journey. And no one knew where they were going. They heard about a city of gold, "El dorado".

They believed that one could walk the streets and pick up gold. So the British promised that they were going to a great place. Yes, they were probably convinced that Guyana was a rich country. The city of "El Dorado". Everyone thought it was a rich place. So they took a chance and left the family. Some returned, others did not.

So this is the Bath Estate? How many people worked here in total? Several hundred people. When my great-grandfather worked here, it was in the late 19th century. It is a long time ago. Do you know anything about how long the working days were then? 12 hours a day. Smallest. Conditions at the time were miserable.

I grew up on the plantation. People had to work long hours. They started at 6 in the morning and ended at 6 in the evening. There was no drinking water here. They collected the water from the roof and drained it into some steel tanks. When it rained? Yes. They drank rainwater.

So this is where my great grandfather prayed?

We do not disturb the gods. But you must take off your shoes when you enter. It smells of smoking. Someone must have been here lately.

How old is this Hindu temple? Let me see. It is probably over 100 years old. Do you remember it from your childhood? Yes. I came here as a little boy. I picked mangoes there. The mango tree is still there. It is an old tree.

Climb in the way. Take your time. I don't want to climb that far up. I climbed the tree as a child. It's a perfect tree to climb.

Hello? How do we open this? Just push. Thanks. Hello! My name is Yasmin. I am so glad to see you. Likewise. This is my daughter, Nayana.

Come on. I am so glad to see you. I live here alone. Yes I know. When did your wife die? Six years ago. Condolences. I sit here alone a lot. When the day comes, I'm really lonely.

But when night comes, I just fall asleep.

Do you know what kind of person my father was? Yes. He was a nice guy. He spoke nicely to people. His charming appearance and ability to chat with the ladies caused a beautiful lady to poison him.

Did the police find out if she had poisoned him? I heard they never found out if it was poisoning. They said it was just a heart attack and did nothing more about it. I can't answer that, But he died of poisoning. We really miss them.

But we know they can't live with us forever.

We are at the first lookout point, Johnson's View. Be careful. These stones are very smooth.

I feel like a 20 year old! Me too!

Hello. Good morning.

Number 406. Gopeah is the name of the immigrant. Your great grandfather. His father's name was Sonehur. Here is actual information about him. Gender: boy. Age: 4.

That means he was four years old. But did he come with his father? No, the father's name is not in the register. He came with his mother.

Does it say that his mother came with him? Yes. In this information about your great-grandfather, it says that the mother came. And here we found your mother's immigration papers. And the information matches. His mother was therefore 25 years old. And she came alone with one child?

Yes. "Next of kin: son, Gopeah." "Mother's Name: Suputty." Gosh! So cool. It is fantastic.

I found Death Certificate No. 67 for Suputty. It indicates that she died in 1867. The following year? So he was five years old when she died? Yes, he was an orphan. Do we know what happened to him? We don't know for sure, but it seems he was adopted by Muslims. He was adopted by Muslims and perhaps vice versa.

Because he was a Hindu, wasn't he? Yes. Suputty is a very Hindu name. So Gopeah was not eleven. No, he was four. And he came here with his mother, who died the following year. Do we know how? Why? Maybe we can find out, but for now we don't know. It could have been domestic violence or natural causes.

Harsh conditions in the colonies. Cholera. We don't have the answers yet. A tough woman. I'm touched. This is cool.

Do you want to play basketball with me?

column2:
Vi kjøpte tradisjonelle klær, som heter kutra, tidlig på dagen. Min var ordentlig bling og flashy. Det var kult å gå i. Jeg følte meg tøff. Fikk god respons av dem som så meg. Vi var i hindutempel. Jeg følte meg ikke helt komfortabel: den hvite karen i kutra.

Men jeg tror folk syntes det var greit. Det var morsomt å se en hvit i kutra. Så det var morsomt. Hvor er vi på vei? Hikkaduwa. Vi skal bade og kose oss. To timer sør for Colombo. Ja. Det er Sri Lankas Gran Canaria, sies det.

Hikkaduwa er en av Sri Lankas mest populære turistdestinasjoner. Her kan du dykke, snorkle, bade. Det er sykt fint her. Man ser ikke land. Bare blått og grønt. Da tsunamien kom, var det noe helt annet. For elleve år siden. Tenk deg det, på ferie med familien ...

Den bølgen! Dobbelt så høy som oss. Hvor høy tror du den var? Den første var liten. Så kom en større bølge. Tok med seg alt. Det var ikke noe igjen. Her står vi og nyter det. For elleve år siden var det ... 26. desember 2004 ble mange land i Indiahavet rammet av en tsunami

som drepte nærmere 300 000. I Hikkaduwa-området var ødeleggelsene enorme. Mange tusen mennesker døde. Nå skal Jeyasanth og Matias besøke en mann som overlevde monsterbølgen.

Her ser dere merkene. Da tsunamien kom, nådde vannet opp hit. Hva gjorde du da? Jeg var utenfor huset. Jeg kan vise dere hvor jeg stod da tsunamien kom. Hva gjorde du? Jeg stod og snakket med noen.

Så så jeg to karer som kom på motorsykkel. Vannet kom inn fra havet. Det første jeg gjorde, var å gå bort dit. Jeg ... fant 17 døde. 17 døde. Og de lå omkring her? Ja.

Jeg kan fortsatt huske det. Jeg fant to her, én der, én der borte ... Det er vanskelig å sette ord på. Jeg er målløs. Det virker litt fjernt, men han har opplevd det. Han har funnet 17 døde her.

Ting vi så i avisene og på YouTube. Jeg syns det var ganske tungt.

Matias er egentlig en kjernekar. Jeg kunne beskrive ham som et fjell. Han er ganske høy. Et fjell. Men som person er han et fjell. Vi var venner fra første klasse. Men da vi var ni-ti år, begynte vi med bryting. Kom an, da!

Når jeg er med Jeyasanth ute, er det bare hudfargen som er forskjellig. Jeg tenker på ham som norsk. Han er en like bra lekekamerat som alle andre. Jeg tror Jeyasanth har hatt flere ting å ta hensyn til. Han må tilpasse seg det tamilske miljøet og det norske.

Jeg er født i Norge, men det er kulturforskjeller. Foreldrene mine kom herfra og har båret med seg identiteten som tamiler. Det har de dyrket i meg fra jeg var liten: tamilsk skole, musikk ... Lære morsmålet, kjenne røttene sine. Jeg husker at du var på Lanka-skole. Er det enkelt? Ikke så enkelt som du tror.

Folk kaller meg kinderegg hvis jeg bare henger med norske. Da kaller folk meg kinderegg: brun utapå og hvit på innsiden. "Hvorfor leker du norsk?" Når jeg er på Sri Lanka og folk spør hvor jeg er fra, sier jeg: "Jeg er tamil." Når jeg er i Norge og folk spør, sier jeg: "Jeg er norsk."

Og noen ganger kan jeg si: "Jeg er norsk-tamil." Hvis du kan språket og er veldig tamilsk overfor familien, kunne du vært sammen med en norsk jente? Hadde de godtatt det? Foreldrene mine sier det, og det gjelder tamiler generelt: "Gjør hva du vil. Men finn helst en tamilsk jente."

Vi er fra forskjellige verdener. Han har Sri Lanka hjemme, men også Norge. Jeg er veldig glad i foreldrene mine. Jeg ville ikke tatt en sånn risiko og ofra familien min for et sånt valg. Såret dem, mistet kontakten og så videre. Det hadde jeg ikke klart.

Jeg forstår Jeyasanth bedre etter å ha sett landet hans og den religiøse delen av livet hans. Jeg har møtt familien hans og sett et genuint srilankisk hjem. Jeg forstår hvorfor han har blitt som han er. Vennskapet med Matias er blitt mye sterkere. Jeg stoler mer på ham.

Han har fått bedre forståelse av hvem jeg er. Nå er vi de gamle gutta som var sammen på Løkka.
column3:
We bought traditional clothes, called kutra, early in the day. Mine was really bling and flashy. It was cool to walk in. I felt tough. Got a good response from those who saw me. We were in a Hindu temple. I didn't feel quite comfortable: the white fellow in the kutra.

But I think people thought it was okay. It was funny to see a white in a kutra. So it was fun. Where are we going? Hiccup. We are going to bathe and enjoy ourselves. Two hours south of Colombo. Yes. It is Sri Lanka's Gran Canaria, they say.

Hikkaduwa is one of Sri Lanka's most popular tourist destinations. Here you can dive, snorkel, swim. It's really nice here. You can't see land. Only blue and green. When the tsunami came, it was something completely different. Eleven years ago. Imagine that, on vacation with the family...

That wave! Twice as tall as us. How tall do you think it was? The first was small. Then came a bigger wave. Took everything with him. There was nothing left. Here we stand and enjoy it. Eleven years ago it was ... On December 26, 2004, many countries in the Indian Ocean were hit by a tsunami

which killed close to 300,000. In the Hikkaduwa area the devastation was enormous. Many thousands of people died. Now Jeyasanth and Matias will visit a man who survived the monster wave.

Here you can see the marks. When the tsunami came, the water reached up here. What did you do then? I was outside the house. I can show you where I was standing when the tsunami came. What did you do? I was talking to someone.

Then I saw two guys coming on a motorcycle. The water came in from the sea. The first thing I did was go over there. I ... found 17 dead. 17 died. And they were lying around here? Yes.

I can still remember it. I found two here, one there, one over there... It's hard to put into words. I'm speechless. It seems a bit far-fetched, but he has experienced it. He has found 17 dead here.

Things we saw in the papers and on YouTube. I think it was quite heavy.

Matias is really a core vessel. I could describe him as a mountain. He is quite tall. A mountain. But as a person he is a mountain. We were friends from first grade. But when we were nine or ten years old, we started wrestling. Come on, then!

When I am with Jeyasanth out, only the skin color is different. I think of him as Norwegian. He is as good a playmate as any other. I think Jeyasanth has had several things to consider. He has to adapt to the Tamil environment and the Norwegian one.

I was born in Norway, but there are cultural differences. My parents came from here and have carried with them the identity as Tamils. They have cultivated that in me since I was little: Tamil school, music ... Learning the mother tongue, knowing one's roots. I remember you were at Lanka school. Is it simple? Not as simple as you think.

People call me Kinderegg if I only hang out with Norwegians. Then people call me Kinderegg: brown on the outside and white on the inside. "Why do you play Norwegian?" When I'm in Sri Lanka and people ask where I'm from, I say, "I'm Tamil." When I'm in Norway and people ask, I say: "I'm Norwegian."

And sometimes I can say: "I am Norwegian-Tamil." If you know the language and are very Tamil towards your family, could you be with a Norwegian girl? Had they accepted it? My parents say it, and it applies to Tamils ​​in general: "Do whatever you want. But preferably find a Tamil girl."

We are from different worlds. He has Sri Lanka at home, but also Norway. I am very happy with my parents. I would not take such a risk and sacrifice my family for such a choice. Hurt them, lost touch and so on. I hadn't been able to do that.

I understand Jeyasanth better after seeing his country and the religious part of his life. I have met his family and seen a genuine Sri Lankan home. I understand why he has become the way he is. The friendship with Matias has become much stronger. I trust him more.

He has gained a better understanding of who I am. Now we are the old guys who were together at Løkka.

Seks unge nordmenn reiser til utlandet for å bli bedre kjent med bestevennene. De avslører historier om mobbing, foreldrepress, krig og kulturkollisjoner. Bli med på reise til Iran, Pakistan, Polen, Israel, Sri Lanka og Irak. Blir de bedre kjent? Nei!

Hei! Vi heter Jeyasanth og Matias. Vi skal til Sri Lanka. Vi gleder oss! Jeyasanth og Matias har vokst opp på Grünerløkka. Vi knuste vinduet. Alle måtte sitte igjen. Når var det? I fjerde, tror jeg. De har alltid snakket om å reise til Sri Lanka. Nå går drømmen i oppfyllelse.

Nå skal vi endelig oppleve det. Jeg gleder meg sykt! Jeg gruer meg litt til å møte familien til Jeyasanth. Det kan bli litt kleint. Det jeg gleder meg mest til, er å møte familien min. Jeg var der sist i 2003. Spiser dere rå insekter, eller? Nei, nei, nei.

Hva er det ekleste dere har? Det ekleste!? Vet du hva ...? Det er ikke ekkelt! Ikke katt, hund ... Dere har kjøtt? Ingen insekter?

Da er vi i lufta. Sri Lanka om tolv ...? Nei, ni timer. Nå er vi på vei. Først til Doha, første stopp. Seks timers flytur. Så Sri Lanka etter det.

Sri Lanka er en perle i Indiahavet med 21 mill. innbyggere og masse tuktuker. Det er varmt året rundt. Mange strender er fortsatt urørt. Hovedstaden er Colombo. Og her bor Jeyasanths familie. Jeg skal endelig møte familien min etter tolv år.

De bor utafor Colombo, så det tar litt tid. En halvtimes tid. De bor ikke i jungelen? Nei ... Så velkomstdrinken er slangeblod. Tuller du? Nei.

Dette er sjukt! Lættis, da!

Den velkomsten! Det var en sånn velkomst som man får i bryllup.

En stund tenkte jeg: Skal jeg gifte meg? Er jeg på vei til ei jente? Kanskje de har gjemt bruden i huset ... Det var som om han skulle gifte seg. Jeg følte meg som forloveren hans. Jeg har ikke ord! Jeg visste ikke at det skulle bli sånn. Skikkelig smak på Sri Lanka. For en velkomst!

Jeg er kongen. Du kan være prinsen. Forskjellen på en norsk og en srilankisk sammenkomst er at vi ikke har musikk. Det er ingen som går med blokkfløyte og trommer. Og vi har ikke ritualene med røykelse og sånt. Det jeg fikk i ansiktet, var visst kubæsj.

Men det skulle være hellig og beskytte mot ondskap, så hvorfor ikke? Det er onkelen min, som har fiksa det meste her. Og fruen hans. Ved siden av henne står søstera til mutter'n. Så sønnene til onkelen min, og dattera. Hun er søstera til mamma. Så tante her, en tante til ...

Og hun er dattera til mamma sin søsters datter der igjen ... Skjønte du? Dette er vennen min. Skjønner dere? Han heter Matias. Nå skal vi spille litt musikk og danse.

Bang! Så var han med. Det var nytt for meg å se Matias sånn.

Uff ... Herregud! Det var deilig. Ikke bare dansen, men å se alle igjen. Kom nærmere. Hva syns du? Rart. Jeg prøvde å slippe meg løs. Hallo! Det er mamma. Jeg vet ikke hva jeg skal si. Matias også elsket det. Alle fikk sjokk. Det var så stort.

Jeg er veldig glad. Jeg har ikke ord for å uttrykke hvordan det føles å møte dere igjen. Og puste i srilankisk luft igjen. Hva gjør du? Studerer du? Jeg går på universitetet. Jeg skal ta eksamen der. Og så har jeg fått meg jobb. Jeg jobber på et telefonsenter. Og jeg har det bra.

Kom, da! Han spiser hele tida. Diger mann. Maten er god! Hva gjør folk på din alder? Vi går på McDonald's eller KFC, vi spiller cricket ... Vi pleier gjerne å dra på tur. Du glemte én ting. Pleier dere ikke å ...?

Du husker det?

Jeyasanth er en gutt med mye humor. Han driver med dans, skuespill og sang. Han er entertainer hele tida. Tar aldri pause fra å være moromann.

Sri Lanka i ett ord så langt: "Jungelboken". Det er det jeg forbinder med Sri Lanka så langt: "Jungelboken". De fleste i familien min var der. Det var helt utrolig. Matias elsket det. Ansiktet hans var et eneste smil, og det varte hele dagen.

Jeg skal lære Matias å spille cricket. Jeg er ikke så god. Men blir nok banens beste. Tviler. Jeg tror jeg vil knuse deg. Team Tigers slår Team Vikings. Team Ice Bear! Cricket er en av verdens største idretter, men nærmest ukjent i Norge. Her spiller nesten alle cricket.

Vi knuser Jeyasanth. Han kan ikke vinne. Skal vi ta dem? Så må dere rope: "Ja!" Skal vi ta dem? JA! Reglene er kompliserte, men la oss prøve: Det er ett innelag og ett utelag. Kasteren prøver å treffe pinnene bak mannen med balltreet.

Klarer han det, er mannen med balltreet slått ut. Treffer mannen med balltreet ballen, må han løpe til andre siden av stripen. Det gir poeng. Tigerne mine kaster nå. Ok, isbjørner, er dere klare?

Din ape, ikke legg fra deg balltreet! Er det ikke baseball vi spiller? De er typisk oss. En av oss må vinne. Jeg har spilt i bakgården. Det vet ikke Jeya.

Det var bra skutt! Dritbra! Vet du hvorfor? Fordi han som kasta, gjorde sitt beste. Og jeg bare spiller rolig. Det var dritbra. Jeg hater å tape. Det var sårt. Men jeg prøvde å late som jeg var glad.

Trafikken i Colombo er rolig sammenlignet med nabolandet India. Siden borgerkrigen tok slutt for 6 år siden, har flere srilankere fått råd til bil. Men fortsatt er det mange som sverger til tuktuk. Jeg har aldri kjørt tuktuk før. Kan du lære meg det?

Så først er det ...? Kløtsj. Det er først, ja. Får du det ikke til? Det er litt vanskelig. Sakte. Han greier det til slutt. Der, der, der! Det var motorstopp. Den vil ikke starte.

Har du kjørt moped? Men du har lappen? Du må skjønne konseptet med kløtsj og greier. Tok du lappen på Lanka-kjøreskole? Jeg har ikke kjørt moped. Jeg trudde alle lankere kjørte tuktuk. Bare vent. Det er skuffende. Dette må du få til.

Ikke kjør fra ham, da. Ikke kjør fra kjørelæreren mens han underviser. Kjør. Sakte. Andre. Så tredje. Du er dårlig! Du er dårlig! Det er viktig å tråkke på motstanderen. Så han ikke har altfor mye selvtillit.

Du satser på meg? Det må du. Vær så snill!

Hvor er du? Hvor er du, white boy? Kom igjen! Kom an, kom an!

Hvor er flagget? Champion of Sri Lanka! Vinner! Hvordan føles det å tape i alt? Greit. Du var flink. Du kom i fart der bak. Lanka boy? Du har ingen framtid her. Dra tilbake til Norge. Tuktuk Champion of Sri Lanka!

Nei, det gjorde vi ikke! Her er jeg! I dag har vi spilt cricket. Jeg knuste Jeya i cricket. Han var storfavoritten på banen. Det var kult. Vær ærlig: Jeg var god. Men jeg var favoritten. Du var hvit. Kanskje jeg var best, rett og slett.

Slo mange sixes, for å si det sånn.

Vi skal shoppe. Jeg er hindu, og vi skal i tempelet. Vi kan ikke ha shorts og slippers. Vi skal kjøpe kurta.

Denne er flott. Det er den vanlige typen.

Fint. Den satt bra. Men du må ha en mørkere farge. Jeg syns den passa til håret. Ja. Men den går i ett med huden.

Sitter fast! Det er så klamt, vet du. Vent. Det henger fast. Dette var litt mer viking-opplegg. Ja. Lærrustning. Jeg likte ikke fargen. Den forrige var bedre. Jeg syns vi skal satse på en bryllupsstil. Litt glorete. Da kan vi ordne bryllup. Leker ikke kurta.

Jeg syns den var kul. Denne? Få se på deg. Oi, oi, oi. Er det frekt å ha mye bling i tempelet? Den var heftig. Mye bedre. Skal vi dra den helt ut? Prøv den. Så blir du helt konge. Jeg har ganske stort hode.

Hvordan føler du deg nå? Som en srilankisk konge. Den kledde deg.

Da er vi kommet på tempelet. Til tempelet. Vi har kommet til tempelet. Dere ser det i bakgrunnen. Vi har pyntet oss. Blitt tradisjonelle gutter. Kjempefine. Helt Lanka. Nå snakker du for lite.

Det var mystisk og eksotisk. Masse inntrykk: lukt, musikk, trommer. Folk gikk rundt med det "håndkleet" rundt livet. Her er Murugan. Hvorfor liker du ham? Han har to koner. Han er playboy-guden? Som Jeya? Nei, jeg er trofast. Hva er det han står for?

Alle gudene står for fred. Det er akkurat det samme her. Det er litt rart. Hva tror du på? Jeg tror det fins noe mer mellom himmel og jord. Jeg har ingen spesiell tilknytning til Gud. Jeg er døpt, men kaller meg ikke kristen. På flyet hit bad jeg til Gud. Sånne ting gir perspektiv på livet.

Når du er redd, noe har skjedd, da ber du til Gud.

Det var skikkelig fint. Hvor religiøs er du? Jeg er ikke den mest religiøse. Men jeg har alltid vært det. For foreldrene mine er ganske religiøse.

Det vanskeligste ved å være fra to forskjellige kulturer er å tilpasse seg. Når jeg er blant tamiler, må jeg være skikkelig tamilsk. Når jeg er blant nordmenn, må jeg være litt mer norsk. Pappa kom som turist. Så søkte han om bosettelse.

Jeg ble født i 1993. Da flytta vi til Oslo. Grünerløkka. Vi vokste opp sammen, ganske tett. Bodde på samme rom, alle fire. Pappa jobbet ganske mye. Det var ikke sånn som ... Når jeg spilte fotballkamp, kom fedrene til de andre. Men pappa var på jobb.

Vi fikk alt vi ønsket oss. Han jobbet dag og natt. Hver gang han kom hjem, så jeg hvor sliten han var. Men han prøvde alltid ...

Vi har alle dårlig samvittighet for alt de har gjort for oss. Jeg vil ikke såre dem. Jeg vil ikke ta med en norsk dame hjem og si: "Vi skal gifte oss!" Det ville såre mamma.

Six young Norwegians travel abroad to get to know their best friends better. They reveal stories of bullying, parental pressure, war and cultural clashes. Join us on a journey to Iran, Pakistan, Poland, Israel, Sri Lanka and Iraq. Do they get to know each other better? No!

Hello! Our names are Jeyasanth and Matias. We are going to Sri Lanka. We look forward! Jeyasanth and Matias grew up in Grünerløkka. We broke the window. Everyone had to sit down. When was it? In the fourth, I think. They have always talked about going to Sri Lanka. Now the dream is coming true.

Now we will finally experience it. I'm really looking forward to it! I am a little dreading meeting Jeyasanth's family. It can be a bit small. What I'm looking forward to the most is meeting my family. I was last there in 2003. Do you eat raw insects, right? No no no.

What is the most disgusting thing you have? The most disgusting thing!? You know what ...? It's not gross! Not cat, dog ... You have meat? No insects?

Then we're in the air. Sri Lanka in twelve ...? No, nine hours. Now we are on our way. First to Doha, first stop. Six hour flight. Then Sri Lanka after that.

Sri Lanka is a pearl in the Indian Ocean with 21 million inhabitants and lots of tuktuks. It is hot all year round. Many beaches are still untouched. The capital is Colombo. And here lives Jeyasanth's family. I will finally meet my family after twelve years.

They live outside Colombo, so it takes some time. Half an hour's time. They don't live in the jungle? No ... So the welcome drink is snake blood. Are you kidding? No.

This is sick! Take it easy, then!

The welcome! It was the kind of welcome you get at a wedding.

For a while I thought: Should I get married? Am I on the way to a girl? Maybe they have hidden the bride in the house ... It was as if he was going to get married. I felt like his fiancé. I do not have words! I didn't know it would turn out like that. Real taste of Sri Lanka. What a welcome!

I am the king. You can be the prince. The difference between a Norwegian and a Sri Lankan gathering is that we don't have music. No one walks around with recorders and drums. And we don't have the rituals of smoking and stuff like that. What I got on my face must have been cow poo.

But it was supposed to be sacred and protect against evil, so why not? It is my uncle who fixed most of the things here. And his wife. Beside her stands the mother's sister. Then the sons of my uncle, and the daughter. She is my mother's sister. So aunt here, another aunt...

And she is the daughter of my mother's sister's daughter there again ... Did you understand? This is my friend. Do you understand? His name is Matias. Now we're going to play some music and dance.

Bang! Then he joined. It was new for me to see Matias like that.

Ugh...Oh my God! It was delicious. Not just the dance, but seeing everyone again. Come closer. What do you think? Weird. I tried to break free. Hello! It's mom. I do not know what to say. Matias also loved it. Everyone was shocked. It was so big.

I am very happy. I have no words to express how it feels to meet you again. And breathe Sri Lankan air again. What are you doing? Do you study? I go to university. I will take the exam there. And then I got a job. I work in a call center. And I'm fine.

Come on! He eats all the time. Huge man. The food is good! What do people your age do? We go to McDonald's or KFC, we play cricket... We like to go on trips. You forgot one thing. Don't you tend to...?

You remember that?

Jeyasanth is a boy with a lot of humor. He does dancing, acting and singing. He is an entertainer all the time. Never takes a break from being funny.

Sri Lanka in one word so far: "The Jungle Book". That's what I associate with Sri Lanka so far: "The Jungle Book". Most of my family was there. It was absolutely incredible. Matias loved it. His face was a single smile and it lasted all day.

I will teach Matias to play cricket. I'm not that good. But will probably be the best on the field. Doubt. I think I want to crush you. Team Tigers beat Team Vikings. Team Ice Bear! Cricket is one of the world's biggest sports, but almost unknown in Norway. Almost everyone plays cricket here.

We crush Jeyasanth. He can't win. Shall we take them? Then you must shout: "Yes!" Shall we take them? YES! The rules are complicated, but let's try: There is one inside team and one outside team. The pitcher tries to hit the pins behind the man with the bat.

If he succeeds, the man with the bat is out. If the man with the bat hits the ball, he must run to the other side of the strip. It gives points. My tigers are throwing now. Okay, polar bears, are you ready?

You monkey, don't put down the bat! Aren't we playing baseball? They are typically us. One of us has to win. I've been playing in the backyard. Jeya doesn't know that.

It was a good shot! Bullshit! Do you know why? Because he who threw, did his best. And I just play calmly. It was pretty good. I hate to lose. It was painful. But I tried to pretend I was happy.

Traffic in Colombo is calm compared to neighboring India. Since the civil war ended 6 years ago, more Sri Lankans have been able to afford a car. But there are still many people who swear by tuktuks. I have never driven a tuktuk before. Can you teach me that?

So first it's…? Clutch. It's first, yes. Can't make it? It's a bit difficult. Slowly. He manages it in the end. There, there, there! It was an engine stop. It won't start.

Have you ridden a moped? But you have the note? You have to understand the concept of clutches and stuff. Did you get your license at Lanka driving school? I have not ridden a moped. I thought all Lankans drove tuktuks. Just wait. It is disappointing. You must achieve this.

Don't run away from him, then. Do not drive away from the driving instructor while he is teaching. Drive. Slowly. Others. Then third. You are bad! You are bad! It is important to step on the opponent. So he doesn't have too much confidence.

You bet on me? You have to. Please!

Where are you? Where are you, white boy? Come on! Come on, come on!

Where is the flag? Champion of Sri Lanka! Winner! How does it feel to lose in everything? Right. You did well. You sped up back there. Lanka boy? You have no future here. Go back to Norway. Tuktuk Champion of Sri Lanka!

No, we didn't! Here I am! Today we played cricket. I crushed Jeya in cricket. He was the big favorite on the pitch. It was cool. Be honest: I was good. But I was the favorite. You were white. Maybe I was simply the best.

Hit a lot of sixes, so to speak.

We're going shopping. I am Hindu and we are going to the temple. We cannot have shorts and flip flops. We are going to buy kurta.

This one is great. It is the common type.

Fine. It fit well. But you must have a darker color. I think it suits the hair. Yes. But it blends in with the skin.

Stuck! It's so sticky, you know. Wait. It's stuck. This was a bit more of a Viking arrangement. Yes. Leather armor. I didn't like the color. The previous one was better. I think we should go for a wedding style. A bit gaudy. Then we can arrange a wedding. Don't play kurta.

I thought it was cool. This? Have a look at you. Oh, oh, oh. Is it rude to wear a lot of bling in the temple? It was intense. Much better. Shall we pull it out completely? Try it. Then you will be completely king. I have quite a big head.

How do you feel now? Like a Sri Lankan king. It dressed you.

Then we have arrived at the temple. To the temple. We have arrived at the temple. You see it in the background. We have decorated ourselves. Became traditional boys. Very nice. All Lanka. Now you talk too little.

It was mysterious and exotic. Lots of impressions: smells, music, drums. People walked around with that "towel" around their waists. Here is Murugan. Why do you like him? He has two wives. He's the playboy god? Like Jeya? No, I am faithful. What does he stand for?

All the gods stand for peace. It's exactly the same here. It's a bit strange. What do you believe in? I think there is something more between heaven and earth. I have no special connection with God. I am baptized, but do not call myself a Christian. On the plane here I prayed to God. Such things give perspective on life.

When you are afraid, something has happened, then you pray to God.

It was really nice. How religious are you? I'm not the most religious. But I always have been. Because my parents are quite religious.

The hardest thing about being from two different cultures is adapting. When I am among Tamils, I must be properly Tamil. When I'm among Norwegians, I have to be a little more Norwegian. Dad came as a tourist. Then he applied for residency.

I was born in 1993. Then we moved to Oslo. Grünerløkka. We grew up together, pretty close. Stayed in the same room, all four. Dad worked quite a lot. It wasn't like that... When I was playing football, the fathers of the others came. But dad was at work.

We got everything we wanted. He worked day and night. Every time he came home, I saw how tired he was. But he always tried…

We all feel guilty for everything they have done for us. I don't want to hurt them. I don't want to bring a Norwegian lady home and say: "We're going to get married!" That would hurt mom.

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

Hvordan møttes dere? Vi var på en nattklubb i sentrum. Der var det ei fin jente, som var sammen med en annen. Hun ga meg telefonnummeret sitt skrevet med lebestift på en serviett. Jenta jeg var sammen med, så det. Jeg sa at hun var ny i byen.

Så du svarte ærlig. Hun så meg jo! Det ville jeg aldri gjort. Litt gammeldags å gi meg nummeret. Du var jo nitten. Jeg var atten. Hun var for ung til å komme inn. Ja, det er sant.

Jeg så at hun danset og syns hun hadde god rytmesans.

Det var ikke vanlig at svarte og hvite var gift. Dessuten var hun blond, som ble holdt for å være det aller vakreste. Du knabber en av våre!

Du sendte meg hit alene for å søke. Ja, det stemmer. Ja, som et par med ulik hudfarge. Så det var lettere for henne på egen hånd.

Jeg måtte være var for slike ting. Lettere å sende hun som er hvit.

Det er altfor lenge siden. Hei, bestemor. Kom hit. Du har alltid vært nummer én. Og se her! Vi er fortsatt familie. Fortsatt familie.

Takk for at du kom. Så godt å se deg. Faren din ville vært stolt av oss. Vi har holdt sammen som familie.

Hva gjør du, David? Dette er fetteren min, Corbin. Det er onkelen min, David. Og bestemor, da. Det var den du ville ha! Er amerikansk mat god fordi den er så feit?

Nei, grønnsaker er ikke feite. Men de tilberedes i fett. Nei. Hvor mye smør? Ingenting. Grønnsaker og litt olivenolje, og det er ikke farlig. Hvis du er redd for å bli tjukk, får du spise mindre.

Sett deg, sett deg! Vil du ha grønnsaker? Forsyn deg.

Ikke gjør sånn!

Hva snakker dere om? Da jeg ikke ville be bordbønn. Ja, det husker jeg. Det ble med den ene gangen. Du må bare senke hodet og late som.

Sånn begynte alt sammen. Hvem er denne jenta? Hvem er hun? Er hun full? Nei, hun har ikke drukket. Se på dette! Det ser ut som at kinnene dine skal sprekke.

Jeg ser ond og feit ut. Ja, du var begge deler. Du var begge deler, barnebarnet mitt.

Dette er et klassisk bilde av familien vår. Det er bare kvinner. Vi er veldig matriarkalske. Dette er tipp-oldemoren min. Og det er bestemor Morris. Dette er min bestemor. Jeg vet ikke så mye om henne selv om jeg vokste opp i nærheten av henne.

Den vakre damen ble til denne vakre damen. Hvordan var hun? Moren min? Hun vokste opp med moren sin. Faren var der av og til. Kvinnene fikk styre, som jeg sa. Hva mener du med av og til?

De var separert, akkurat slik mine foreldre ble da jeg var tre år. Det er sprøtt at alle blir separert. Ja, kvinnene må ta seg av det. Ekteskap er ikke vår spesialitet. Vi har mange andre gode egenskaper.

I morgen drar du. Dette var én del av historien.

Jeg tror det blir bra. Det er bra for ham. Og det er bra for deg. Du får bli kjent med ham på egne premisser og gjøre deg opp en mening. Det er viktig. Det er derfor jeg vil dra alene. Men det er jo litt rart.

Jeg syns det var en merkelig idé, men det handler ikke om meg. Hvorfor syns du det var merkelig? Det er jeg som har tatt meg av dere. Og nå kommer plutselig en som ikke har deltatt, inn i bildet.

Du er det viktigste oppi dette. Det er deg han må forklare seg for. Det var godt å se deg. God tur videre. Takk. Kos deg. Det har vært fantastisk! Helt fantastisk! Jeg er glad i deg. Glad i deg også, barnebarn nr. én!

Og ta på deg sko når du skal ut.

Hei. Nei, har du sett? Vil du spille basketball med meg? Godt å se deg. Vi er så glad for å se deg. Velkommen til Huntsville. Takk. Det er første gang jeg er i Alabama.

Han er høy, akkurat som Arthur. Og like bred som Arthur! Vi må nok droppe basketball-scenen. Jeg kommer ikke til å kunne bryne meg på han her.

Skal jeg ta av skoene? Nei! Disse tre er guttene til Vanessa. Datteren min, sønnen min, nevøen min og sønnene mine. Jaleel er sønnen til datteren vår Kimberley. Hun bor i California. Han kom hit for å gå på skole.

Jeg hadde sett for meg litt av hvert. Det er jo Alabama. Men det er veldig fint her.

Skal vi spille horse? Nei, vi spiller 21 i stedet. Begynn du. Jeg tar utfordringen. Du kommer til å angre. Ett poeng til meg!

Hadde du greid det før i tida? Er du ikke i form i dag? I dag er jeg bare gammel.

Fortell om da du spilte. Jeg spilte på videregående. Jeg var ganske flink. Jeg spilte for Copiague High School. Copiague på Long Island. Jeg likte å spille, og familien min kom for å se.

Det var gøy. Fikk du kjenne på stjernestatusen? Ja, vi var i avisa. Bilder av scoringer. Jeg har ei bok med alle bildene av det. Vi kunne lese om det i avisa dagen etter at vi hadde slått et annet lag.

John Bailey scoret 24 poeng. Hvorfor sluttet du? Det var ikke lett. Jeg måtte jobbe. Jeg hadde ikke tid lenger. Jeg jobbet på kveldstid. Leste når jeg hadde tid.

Jeg fikk vitnemål. Det er det viktigste.

Jeg har bra stil selv om jeg ikke scorer. Så lenge du ser proff ut! Da spiller det ingen rolle hvordan det går. Sånn, ja! Hvis du har en veldig feminin stil, kaster du bedre.

Hvis du bøyer håndleddet slik, går den i kurva. De gode basketballspillerne får til den bevegelsen.

Vi er glad for at du ville være med å feire 96-årsdagen hennes. På full fart mot 100! Gratulerer med dagen. Gratulerer, kjære mor.

Gratulerer med dagen. Hvor gammel er du? Så gammel at jeg ikke husker. Håper vi alle kan leve så lenge at vi glemmer hvor lenge. Jeg har med litt kake til deg. Liker du jordbær?

Er det en smak du liker? Det er jorbærkake. Vil du ha litt? Ja? Er den god, tror du?

Var det all glasuren? Oi!

Det er ingen gravsteiner, for det var dårlige registre. Slaver ble regnet for å være eiendom. Vi har ikke navnene på dem. Derfor satte vi opp gravsteiner som denne

som et symbol for alle slavene som ligger her. Hvordan artet livet seg for slavene? Det var beinhardt. Jorda her var vanskelig å dyrke opp. Så det var mye hardt arbeid

for å få til å dyrke bomull her den gangen. Det er så merkelig å tenke på hvordan det var. Det er ufattelig. Ja. Men så kommer ungdommer som deg hit og får seg en utdannelse. Rektoren vår sier at nå kan man få en utdannelse

på den blodstenkte grunnen hvor plantasjene sto. Sterke ord.

Takk. Amen. Hvor mange her vet at Herren er god?

De fleste her er afroamerikanere. Hvorfor det? Vi er i Sørstatene. I Sørstatene er det vanlig å ha ensartede menigheter. De fleste i forsamlingen er afroamerikanske, men de kommer fra hele verden.

Alle de som er her for første gang, kan reise seg opp. Hvis det er første gang du er her, eller er med noen andre. Er det noen oppe på galleriet? Reis dere opp. Amen.

Hun hadde en vakker stemme. Hun sang som en fugl. Vi ble kjærester. Hun kom og så på når jeg spilte basketballkamp. Vi var ungdomskjærester. Så ble vi gift. Vi var altfor unge. Hvor gammel var du?

Jeg var en 17-18 år. Det var tidlig. Ja, det var litt for tidlig. Vi fikk tre flotte gutter. Hva skjedde? Det fungerte ikke. Jeg giftet meg på nytt og flyttet til Huntsville.

Jeg hadde ikke tenkt å forsvinne helt. Jeg ville ha et forhold til guttene. Jeg prøvde å få det til, og jeg foreslo at de skulle bli med hit. Men jeg visste at de ikke ville reise fra moren sin, og det forstår jeg. Hva skjedde etter det?

Faren din hadde nok den oppfatningen at jeg var mer opptatt av den nye familien min enn av guttene. Det såret ham. Han ville ikke ha noe mer med meg å gjøre.

Hvis noen ikke har lyst til å være sammen med meg, vil ikke jeg være den som presser meg på. Så jeg lot det være. Vi er glad i hverandre fremdeles. Jeg følger med ham på Facebook. Alle stedene han har reist til, og de fine klærne han går i.

Jeg følger med selv om jeg ikke sier noe. Jeg hadde ikke gjort det hvis jeg ikke brydde meg. Jeg møtte far før jeg kom hit. Jeg merket at han syns det er vanskelig. Hvis du får faren din til å komme,

tar vi gjerne imot både ham, kona og ungen. Det blir som om ingenting har hendt. Vi trenger ikke snakke slik du og jeg gjør nå engang. Vi trenger ikke dvele ved det. Vi kan heller se framover. Det ville løst alt sammen.

Jeg er 73 år. Jeg har ikke mange år igjen. Du blir nok 100! Du har mange år igjen. Men har du den samme livskvaliteten i den alderen? Arthur, er det deg? Ja, det er meg!

Du så jo oldemoren din i går. Det er nesten bare hvisking. Men hun likte kaka. Hun er våken når det er snakk om kake. Det får hun med seg.
column3:
<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

How did you meet? We were at a night club in the city centre. There was a nice girl there, who was with someone else. She gave me her phone number written in lipstick on a napkin. The girl I was with saw it. I said she was new in town.

So you answered honestly. She saw me! I would never do that. A bit old-fashioned to give me the number. You were nineteen. I was eighteen. She was too young to enter. Yes it is true.

I saw her dancing and I think she had a good sense of rhythm.

It was not common for blacks and whites to be married. Besides, she was blonde, which was considered to be the most beautiful of all. You bite one of ours!

You sent me here alone to search. Yes, that's right. Yes, like a couple with different skin color. So it was easier for her on her own.

I had to be wary of such things. Easier to send a female who is white.

It's been far too long. Hi Grandma. Come here. You have always been number one. And look here! We are still family. Still family.

Thank you for coming. So good to see you. Your father would be proud of us. We have stayed together as a family.

What are you doing, David? This is my cousin, Corbin. That's my uncle, David. And grandmother, then. That's the one you wanted! Is American food good because it's so greasy?

No, vegetables are not fatty. But they are cooked in fat. No. How much butter? Nothing. Vegetables and a little olive oil, and it's not dangerous. If you are afraid of getting fat, you get to eat less.

Sit down, sit down! Do you want vegetables? Help yourself.

Don't do that!

What are you talking about? When I didn't want to pray table prayer. Yes, I remember that. It was with the one time. You just have to put your head down and pretend.

That's how it all started. Who is this girl? Who is she? Is she drunk? No, she hasn't been drinking. Look at this! Your cheeks look like they're going to burst.

I look mean and fat. Yes, you were both. You were both, my grandson.

This is a classic picture of our family. It's only women. We are very matriarchal. This is my great-great grandmother. And that's Grandma Morris. This is my grandmother. I don't know much about her even though I grew up near her.

The beautiful lady turned into this beautiful lady. How was she? My mom? She grew up with her mother. The father was there occasionally. The women were allowed to rule, as I said. What do you mean by occasionally?

They were separated, just like my parents were when I was three years old. It's crazy that everyone is being separated. Yes, the women have to take care of it. Marriage is not our specialty. We have many other good qualities.

Tomorrow you leave. This was one part of the story.

I think it will be good. It's good for him. And it's good for you. You get to know him on your own terms and make up your own mind. It is important. That's why I want to go alone. But it's a bit strange.

I think it was a strange idea, but it's not about me. Why do you think that was strange? I am the one who took care of you. And now suddenly someone who has not participated enters the picture.

You are the most important thing in this. You are the one he has to explain himself to. It was good to see you. Have a good trip. Thanks. Enjoy. It has been fantastic! Fantastic! I love you. Happy for you too, grandchild number one!

And wear shoes when you go out.

Hello. No, have you seen? Do you want to play basketball with me? Good to see you. We are so glad to see you. Welcome to Huntsville. Thanks. It's my first time in Alabama.

He is tall, just like Arthur. And as wide as Arthur! We'll probably have to ditch the basketball scene. I'm not going to be able to get over him here.

Should I take off my shoes? No! These three are Vanessa's boys. My daughter, my son, my nephew and my sons. Jaleel is the son of our daughter Kimberley. She lives in California. He came here to go to school.

I had envisioned a bit of everything. It's Alabama, after all. But it is very nice here.

Shall we play horse? No, we play 21 instead. You begin. I take the challenge. You will regret it. One point for me!

Had you managed it in the past? Are you not in shape today? Today I'm just old.

Tell us about when you played. I played in high school. I was pretty good. I played for Copiague High School. Copiague on Long Island. I enjoyed playing and my family came to watch.

It was fun. Did you feel the star status? Yes, we were in the newspaper. Pictures of scores. I have a book with all the pictures of it. We could read about it in the newspaper the day after we had beaten another team.

John Bailey scored 24 points. Why did you quit? It wasn't easy. I had to work. I didn't have time anymore. I worked in the evenings. I read when I had time.

I got a diploma. That is the most important thing.

I have good style even if I don't score. As long as you look pro! Then it doesn't matter how it goes. There you go! If you have a very feminine style, you throw better.

If you bend your wrist like this, it goes into a curve. The good basketball players get that movement.

We are delighted that you wanted to join us in celebrating her 96th birthday. Full speed towards 100! Happy Birthday. Congratulations, dear mother.

Happy Birthday. How old are you? So old I don't remember. Hope we can all live long enough to forget how long. I have brought you some cake. Do you like strawberries?

Is there a flavor you like? It's yarrow cake. Would you like some? Yes? Is it good, do you think?

Was that all the icing? Oh!

There are no gravestones, because there were bad records. Slaves were considered property. We don't have their names. That's why we put up gravestones like this one

as a symbol for all the slaves who lie here. What was life like for the slaves? It was bone-chilling. The soil here was difficult to cultivate. So it was a lot of hard work

to get cotton grown here at the time. It's so strange to think what it was like. It's unbelievable. Yes. But then young people like you come here and get an education. Our headmaster says that now you can get an education

on the blood-spattered ground where the plantations stood. Strong words.

Thanks. Amen. How many here know that the Lord is good?

Most people here are African American. Why? We are in the Southern States. In the southern states it is common to have uniform congregations. Most of the congregation is African-American, but they come from all over the world.

All those who are here for the first time can stand up. If it's your first time here, or you're with someone else. Is anyone up at the gallery? Get up. Amen.

She had a beautiful voice. She sang like a bird. We became lovers. She came and watched when I played basketball. We were teenage sweethearts. Then we got married. We were far too young. How old were you?

I was a 17-18 year old. It was early. Yes, it was a little too early. We had three beautiful boys. What happened? It did not work. I remarried and moved to Huntsville.

I didn't intend to disappear completely. I wanted a relationship with the boys. I tried to make it happen, and I suggested that they should come here. But I knew they didn't want to leave their mother, and I understand that. What happened after that?

Your father was probably of the opinion that I was more concerned with my new family than with the boys. It hurt him. He wanted nothing more to do with me.

If someone doesn't want to be with me, I won't be the one to push. So I let it be. We still love each other. I follow him on Facebook. All the places he has traveled to, and the nice clothes he wears.

I follow even if I don't say anything. I wouldn't have done it if I didn't care. I met father before I came here. I noticed that he finds it difficult. If you make your father come,

we are happy to welcome him, his wife and the child. It will be as if nothing has happened. We don't even have to talk like you and I do now. We need not dwell on it. We can rather look ahead. That would solve everything.

I am 73 years old. I don't have many years left. You'll probably be 100! You have many years left. But do you have the same quality of life at that age? Arthur, is that you? Yes it is me!

You saw your great-grandmother yesterday. It's almost a whisper. But she liked the cake. She is alert when it comes to cake. She gets that with her.

column2:
Men du har aldri fortalt noe særlig om hvorfor dere drog i utgangspunktet. Vi drog egentlig på grunn av bestemor, altså mormor. Hun flytta først. Og så var det så bra at hun ville vi skulle flytte etter. Samtidig gikk moren min fra faren min, så det passa egentlig bra.

Jeg vet lite om faren. Hun har så vidt nevnt ham. Og da har jeg skjønt at det har vært problematisk. Du har aldri sagt: "Pappa? Nei, han sitter i fengsel ..." Jeg har aldri gravd noe i det. Jeg kjenner ham ikke. Kanskje han har en god jobb og familie et sted.

Bor han der vi skal nå? Har ikke peiling på hvor han er. Hvor lenge er det siden du så ham? Jeg har ikke sett ham siden 2003. Det er så lenge siden, ja. Det var begravelsen til farmora mi. Etter at vi flytta til Norge, kom han på besøk en gang i året.

Og det var primært for å fiske. For å besøke moren sin, som også bodde i Norge. Og så besøkte han oss. Så nå blåser du i faren din? Eller hvordan er det nå? Nei, det blir veldig vanskelig å ...

Ha meninger om en person man ikke kjenner. Så da han forsvant fra livet mitt, følte jeg ikke noe savn.

Vi skal til Wroc¼aw, hvor Dominika bodde før hun og moren flyttet til Norge.

Wroc¼aw er en av Polens største og eldste byer. Turistene drar helst til gamlebyen, kjent for sitt vakre rådhus og gamle kirker. I dette været utsetter vi besøket til barndomshjemmet. Vi går på shoppingsenter. Dominika vil vise hva slags godteri hun likte som barn. Kondensert melk er meningsløst. Da skulle det vært gassform. Og så har vi hundechips.

Jeg hater godterismaken din. Men jeg vil gi dette en sjanse. Karamell ... Kom igjen, da! Det var vondt. Jeg hater jo potetgull. Jeg vil gjerne at du skal beskrive konsistensen og hva du tenker ...?

Ostepop, fullstendig uten smak. Melk på tube? Nei, nei, nei. Æsj! Det ser akkurat ut som sæd. Du tar litt i munnen. Nå må du gi deg! Nå kødder du sykt!

Melk som er helt lik sæd, og man skal ta det i munnen. Jeg veit ikke, jeg. Det er veldig kvalmende.

Vi er på vei til gata jeg bodde i som barn. Jeg vil vise André blokka jeg bodde i, fortelle litt om området. Derfor har jeg med Beata, ei venninne av mamma. Hun bodde der samtidig med oss og kan fortelle litt mer om stedet.

Nå er vi her. Hvor gammel var du da du bodde her? Fra du ble født, til du var ...? Til jeg var seks. Ja, dette er et klassisk polsk blokkområde. Men dette er et mindre velstående område? Det var en bydel med vanlige folk, folk som jobba. Det var ikke sosialboliger i området.

Men det er ikke noe rikt område, ser man. Den? Det er faktisk den leiligheten, i første etasje. Det var spennende. Høre om hvordan det var. I en leilighet på 55 kvadrat bodde fire personer i ett rom, en person i naborommet og enda en i et annet rom. Det er ganske trangt. Som asylmottaket i Mysen.

Det så ikke jævlig ut, men ... det var på en måte ... Jeg får inntrykk av at dere var ganske fattige. Hva regner du som fattig? Når André sier at jeg vokste opp i en "getto", er det bare morsomt.

Det viser Andrés uvitenhet om hva en getto egentlig er. Var det hyggelig, eller noe dere måtte fordi dere var blakke? Vi måtte bo trangt fordi vi hadde lite penger. Jeg kalte det getto og slum mest for å kødde med Dominika. Men det er litt sant. Jeg tror jeg har slektninger der ennå. Jeg tror broren til faren min bor der.

Men jeg er ikke helt sikker. Hvor mange ganger har du vært her siden du flytta? Skal vi gå inn og se? Skal vi gå opp? Her har jeg ikke vært siden jeg flytta. Det er en etasje opp. Jeg tør ikke gå opp.

Er det noen sjanse for at faren din er der? Som du ikke har sett på 15 år. Teoretisk sett, ja. Men bare hvis onkelen min bor her og faren min tilfeldigvis er på besøk. Åssen hadde han reagert hvis du hadde dukka opp? Jeg vet ikke, for jeg kjenner ham ikke.

Hjertet mitt slår litt. Dette er litt spennende. Jeg følte meg litt teit som syntes det var spennende. Dette var hennes tur. Men det virket nesten mest spennende for meg. Hadde jeg dratt tilbake til barndomshjemmet, ville det vært veldig spennende. Men du som ikke har vært her ...? Siden jeg var seks.

Hva vil jeg med å ringe på? Hva oppnår jeg egentlig? Jeg ønsker ikke kontakt. Da er det meningsløst å ringe på. Jeg tror hun er litt splitta. Hun vil ikke ha noe med ham å gjøre. Samtidig er det ikke noe som går ut over hverdagen hennes.

Men ... Jeg ville bare se leiligheten. Men ok. Det er veldig gøy å være her inne.

Det må være veldig gøy å se ting du ikke har sett på lenge. Jeg husker denne bakken som veldig ... Jeg veit ikke. Jeg har ikke noen traumatiske opplevelser herfra. Det jeg lurer på når jeg står her nå, er

hva som hadde skjedd hvis vi hadde blitt, ikke flytta da jeg var seks. Hvor lenge hadde vi fortsatt å bo i denne blokka? Hvor hadde jeg flytta etterpå? Hva hadde jeg gjort?

Jeg og Dominika har vært veldig gode venner veldig lenge. Jeg er blitt mye bedre kjent med henne gjennom turen. Særlig fordi hun har tatt meg med på veldig personlige ting. Det var ikke den beste delen av livet mitt, men det var gøy å vise André.

Fordi han har sett hvor jeg kommer fra. Han har vært i oppgangen til blokka mi. Selv eksen min var ikke der. Vær ærlig: Det er litt slum her!

De ser på rumpa di. Den er dekket. Det går bra. Pakistan er stort for meg. Mitt hjerte.
column3:
But you never said anything in particular about why you left in the first place. We actually went because of grandma, meaning grandmother. She moved first. And then it was so good that she wanted us to move after. At the same time, my mother separated from my father, so it actually fits well.

I know little about the father. She has barely mentioned him. And then I realized that it has been problematic. You never said, "Dad? No, he's in jail..." I never dug into that. I don't know him. Maybe he has a good job and family somewhere.

Does he live where we are going? No idea where he is. How long has it been since you saw him? I haven't seen him since 2003. It's been that long, yes. It was my grandmother's funeral. After we moved to Norway, he came to visit once a year.

And it was primarily for fishing. To visit his mother, who also lived in Norway. And then he visited us. So now you blow on your father? Or how is it now? No, it will be very difficult to…

Have opinions about a person you don't know. So when he disappeared from my life, I didn't feel any loss.

We are going to Wroc¼aw, where Dominika lived before she and her mother moved to Norway.

Wroc¼aw is one of Poland's largest and oldest cities. Tourists prefer to go to the old town, known for its beautiful town hall and old churches. In this weather, we are postponing the visit to the childhood home. We go to the shopping centre. Dominika wants to show what kind of candy she liked as a child. Condensed milk is pointless. Then it should have been in gaseous form. And then we have dog chips.

I hate your candy flavor. But I will give this a chance. Caramel ... Come on, then! It was painful. I hate potato chips. I would like you to describe the consistency and what you think...?

Cheese pop, completely tasteless. Milk in a tube? No no no. Yuck! It looks just like semen. You take some in your mouth. Now you have to give in! Now you fuck sick!

Milk that is exactly like semen, and you have to take it in your mouth. I don't know, me. It is very nauseating.

We are on our way to the street I lived in as a child. I want to show André the block I lived in, tell a little about the area. That's why I have Beata, a friend of my mother's, with me. She lived there at the same time as us and can tell a little more about the place.

Now we are here. How old were you when you lived here? From the time you were born, until you were...? Until I was six. Yes, this is a classic Polish block area. But this is a less prosperous area? It was a district with ordinary people, people who worked. There were no social housing in the area.

But it is not a rich area, you see. It? It's actually that apartment, on the first floor. That was exciting. Hear about how it was. In an apartment of 55 square metres, four people lived in one room, one person in the neighboring room and another in another room. It's quite tight. Like the asylum reception in Mysen.

It didn't look like much, but... it was kind of... I get the impression you guys were pretty poor. What do you consider poor? When André says I grew up in a "ghetto", it's just funny.

It shows André's ignorance of what a ghetto really is. Was it nice, or something you had to do because you were broke? We had to live cramped because we had little money. I called it ghetto and slum mostly to screw with Dominika. But it is somewhat true. I think I still have relatives there. I think my father's brother lives there.

But I'm not entirely sure. How many times have you been here since you moved? Shall we go in and see? Shall we go upstairs? I haven't been here since I moved. It's one floor up. I don't dare go up.

Any chance your father is there? Like you haven't seen in 15 years. Theoretically, yes. But only if my uncle lives here and my father happens to be visiting. Åssen would he have reacted if you had appeared? I don't know, because I don't know him.

My heart beats a little. This is a bit exciting. I felt a bit stupid for finding it exciting. This was her turn. But it seemed almost the most exciting to me. If I went back to my childhood home, it would be very exciting. But you who haven't been here...? Since I was six.

What do I want to call? What do I actually achieve? I do not want contact. Then it is pointless to call. I think she's a little torn. She wants nothing to do with him. At the same time, there is nothing that goes beyond her everyday life.

But ... I just wanted to see the apartment. But okay. It's a lot of fun to be in here.

It must be a lot of fun to see things you haven't seen in a long time. I remember this hill as very ... I don't know. I don't have any traumatic experiences from here. What I'm wondering as I stand here now is

what would have happened if we had stayed, not moved when I was six. How long had we continued to live in this block? Where would I have moved afterwards? What had I done?

Me and Dominika have been very good friends for a very long time. I got to know her much better during the trip. Especially because she has taken me on very personal things. It wasn't the best part of my life, but it was fun to show André.

Because he's seen where I'm coming from. He has been in the rise of my block. Even my ex wasn't there. Be honest: it's a bit of a slum here!

They're looking at your ass. It is covered. It goes well. Pakistan is big for me. My heart.

column2:
<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

Seks unge nordmenn reiser til utlandet for å bli bedre kjent med bestevennene. De avslører historier om mobbing, foreldrepress, krig og kulturkollisjoner. Bli med på reise til Iran, Pakistan, Polen, Israel, Sri Lanka og Irak. Blir de bedre kjent? Nei!

Hei. Jeg heter Dominika. André. Vi skal til Polen, som jeg opprinnelig er fra. Hva vet du om Polen? Jeg veit at de snekrer og plukker bær i Norge. Hva de gjør i Polen, vet jeg ikke. Fordommene mine sier at de spiser kål. Det er sant. Dominika og André har vært venner siden videregående i Mysen.

Limet i vennskapet er humor. Humoren til André. En god blanding av antihumor og humor som bare han skjønner.

Det er mange polakker som jobber som renholdere. Kanskje kvalitetsvaskeutstyr fra Norge? Jeg vil gjerne seg deg overrekke denne til tanta mi. I dag skal de kjøpe gaver til Dominikas onkel i Polen. Men han blir ikke fornærma hvis jeg har med kål fra Norge i gave?

Han får bruk for det. Dominika og familien har feriert i Polen. Men det er første gang hun har med en kamerat. Det føles veldig rart å ha med André. Han er en venn som setter pris på sånt. Jeg er ganske spent på å møte familien til Dominika.

Hun snakker ikke mye om røttene sine. Jeg tror Polen er et kjedelig land. Jeg tror ikke det skjer så mye der.

Moja ulubiona czekolada. Polsk har 70 % konsonanter. Det er en utfordring å få til noe som kan uttales. Det føles som å snakke tullespansk. Onkelen til Dominika bor i Miedzyzdroje. Byen ligger langs Østersjøen og har 6000 innbyggere.

Om sommeren blir tallet mangedoblet når polske og tyske badeturister kommer. Byen er en kjent spadestinasjon, og det går ferje til København og Ystad. Nå er det middag hos Dominikas onkel og tante. Hei. Hei, lille Dominika.

På polsk vis ... Hei, lille Dominika. Jeg ser at katten er på bordet. Det er tradisjon her. God kveld. Marian. André. Moja ulubiona czekolada. Tusen takk! Rett før jeg skulle inn til dem, stod jeg utafor og pugga gloser.

Jeg er sykt dårlig på språk. Nå kommer den vanskelige ... Norweska kapusta. Det er ikke mulig ... Den ligner sin polske tvillingsøster. Å nei! Den er norsk. He-he-he. Kål, ja ... Sure ble de ikke.

Onkel betyr mye for meg. Han er ... Den utenom mor og broren min som står meg nærmest. Han spør om vi har klina. Si ja. Han kødder mye med meg.

Vanlige folk pleier å kysse i Polen. Men i noen situasjoner bør man ikke kysse. Han sier at det generelt er tillatt å kline i Polen. Det er lov. Jeg og André ble kjent i Mysen da jeg var 14 og han 15. Jeg var veldig outsider i Mysen. Har spesiell oppvekst og bakgrunn.

Jeg og André ble venner over et bilde av aspargesbønner. Annerledesheten gjorde at vi ble kjent. Hvordan syns du det smaker? Det var mye attention. Veldig godt. Det er ikke så fjernt fra norsk mat.

Det er tre farger: beige, brunt og lysebrunt. Alltid. Det ser ikke appetittlig ut, men er utrolig godt. Og mye mer smak enn i norsk mat. Polakker syns norsk mat er kjedelig. De hadde noe grusom sopp som var helt krise, liksom.

Jeg tror det var hele sjampinjonger i eddik. Det smaker veldig eddik. Du syns dette er godt? Ja, det er min favoritt. Det er bra at André sier det han tenker. Maten vi fikk servert, var veldig 50-50. Eller hva skal man si? 20-80, for å være hyggelig.

God og sterk! Jeg tåler ingenting. Det er en skam. Jeg er fra Mysen. Jeg fikk den som var rundt 40 %. André fikk 80. Det er jo dop. Dominika tåler mer enn meg. Lillesøsteren min tåler mer. Jeg blir fort full. Har det fort gøy.

Lommekniv, lommekniv blir jeg kalt her i byen, av folk som kjenner sannheten. Jeg kjenner ikke til, jeg kjenner ikke til teksten videre ...

Etter middagen vil Dominika ta André med på disco polo i nabobyen. Disco polo er inspirert av eurodance og krydret med polsk folkemusikk.

Jeg tenkte: Så mye folk har det så gøy til denne jævlige musikken! Det er tjåka fullt med blodharry polakker som har det gøy til ekstremt tacky, veldig fengende polsk musikk. Folk var kjempeglade. Alle syntes det var gøy, alle dansa. Det var god stemning. Man blei glad av å være der.

Hva synes du om disco polo? Jeg vil heller kalle det polsk dance. Disco polo er fra 90-tallet. Polsk dance er det vi spiller her nå. Den skiller seg fra musikk fra 90-tallet fordi den ligner mer på moderne musikk. Musikken har polsk tekst. Mens melodien er dansbar og minst like bra som i Vesten.

Vi drakk like mye. Men jeg tålte mye mer. Da vi kom til disco polo- stedet, var jeg veldig edru. Det var ikke han. Jeg måtte drikke for å orke å være der. De prøvde ikke å være kule. Det var ganske kult. Alle syns tacky musikk er catchy. Men ikke alle vil innrømme det.

Folk koser seg og har ingen hemninger. Hvis du går på fylla i Oslo, drar på Angst eller noe på Youngstorget, så er folk veldig forsiktige og passer på utseendet. Men her gir de blaffen. Dette er en sjanger som folk ikke tør å vedkjenne seg at de liker. Men likevel lever sjangeren i beste velgående. Det liker jeg.

Det er den musikksjangeren jeg husker som Polen. Polen for meg.

Disco polo, herregud! Polakkene har en måte å feste på som er jævlig genuin! Og jeg har vært hos familien til Dominika. Onkelen til Domi: jordnær og trivelig type. Og vi skal i katolsk kirke i morgen. Fyllesjuk og jævlig! God natt!

Vi skal til gudstjeneste i en katolsk kirke. Eller messe, som det kalles. Hvordan er formen? Begynner å komme seg. Rett fra disco polo til gudstjeneste? Fra synd til tilgivelse.

I barndommen hadde jeg og broren min noen av de beste latterkrampene i kirken. For man skal sitte og holde kjeft. Men klarer det ikke, fordi noen synger falskt, en prest står og pusser sølv ... Holder et oblat opp. Alt er merkelig. Ekstremt annerledes enn jeg er vant til fra oppveksten i pinsemenighet.

Der er det et pluss å slippe seg løs og være gæren. Riste på golvet, tale i tunger ... Mens dette var pyntelig og pent. Alle reiser seg og setter seg samtidig. Jeg er faktisk døpt i denne kirken. Selv om jeg ikke er religiøs. Har ikke vært det på lenge.

Jeg var det ikke, men ble tvunget til å gå i kirken. Jeg sa til moren min: Vet du, jeg tror ikke på dette. Åssen tok hun det? Ikke bra. Det var ikke lov å snakke om. Jeg har vært kristen mesteparten av livet. Frem til jeg var 18. Men fra pinsemenigheten.

Jeg slutta liksom å tro på én og én ting, fra jeg var ... Si fra 14-15 til 18. Da la jeg fra meg én og én ting. Hva var det første du slutta å tro på? På et tidspunkt får man naturfagundervisning på skolen.

Og da skjønner man at jorda ikke er 6000 år gammel, som vi er indoktrinert.

Tilbake på hotellet etter dag 2. Drog rett på katolsk messe. Jeg har fått glorie etter det. I morgen skal jeg være arbeidsinnvandrer i Polen.

Hvordan tror du det blir å jobbe i Polen? Jeg tror det blir bra. Lønna er ikke all verden. Onkelen din eier jo firmaet. Jeg antar at de fleste kan engelsk.

Dominikas onkel driver et byggfirma. Nå skal et gammelt hus pusses opp. Andrés makker heter Georg og snakker litt engelsk. Hva med hjelm? Bruker du hjem? Hjelm bruker man på byggeplasser, ikke her.

Burde du ikkje bruke ansiktsmaske? Jeg har maske i bilen. Han kommer til å få lungeproblemer innen et halvt år. Det sykt mye støv her. Man får masse gips i lungene. Jobbe, jobbe, jobbe. Tydeligvis krangla jeg for mye om HMS. Til slutt fikk jeg bare beskjed om å jobbe.

Det er litt gøy at André har holdt på i ti minutter, og er allerede sliten og begynner å surne.

André, denne er til deg. Takk. Nå, hva syns du? Har du revet alt det? Vi delte på midten. Du ser at han er kommet mye lenger. Sånn har jeg aldri sett André. Og det får jeg neppe se igjen.

Georg var jo supermacho, og selvsagt drev han med kampsport. Så da tenkte jeg det ville vært moro om han kunne vise meg noe. Men så ble han superblyg. Du lovet å vise meg noen jiu-jitsu-grep. Nå? Oi ... Ok, da. Så fortalte jeg at jeg drev med rapping.

Vi avtalte at jeg skulle rappe på norsk og han skulle vise meg kampsport. Bilen er på Vesteng, lyden på Måsan. Ruller rundt i Volvo med 96 i påsan. Fester ikke drøyt nok, spiller ikke høyt nok før de klager fra Vestereng og Høytorp. Henger på Mørstad, henger på Trøgstad ... Likte du det? Dobre!

Jeg tror han syntes André var veldig spesiell. "Hva slags mann er dette?"

Unnskyld. Du fikk hjelmen min i ansiktet. Du er god. Han virka som en skikkelig hyggelig type. Han var en Mysen-type. Virka ... Men han hadde ingeniørutdannelse. Det er ikke typisk Mysen. Men han hadde en typisk Mysen-jobb.

Når jeg er på ferie, pleier jeg å kjøpe det styggeste kortet jeg finner. Her er et postkort med rav. Se der, da. Dette er helt nydelig! De styggeste postkortet jeg har sett. Det ligger en stein inni! Der er et enda styggere. Mitt navn burde være her. Der! Nøkkelring med navnet mitt.

Jeg føler meg veldig norsk. Absolutt. Jeg er norsk. Hjemmefølelsen i Polen ble mindre for hvert eneste år vi bodde i Norge. Men jeg er veldig glad i å reise dit på besøk til familien. Og stolt av å være fra Polen.
column3:
<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

Six young Norwegians travel abroad to get to know their best friends better. They reveal stories of bullying, parental pressure, war and cultural clashes. Join us on a journey to Iran, Pakistan, Poland, Israel, Sri Lanka and Iraq. Do they get to know each other better? No!

Hello. My name is Dominika. Others. We are going to Poland, which I am originally from. What do you know about Poland? I know that they do carpentry and pick berries in Norway. What they do in Poland, I don't know. My prejudices say they eat cabbage. It is true. Dominika and André have been friends since high school in Mysen.

The glue in friendship is humour. The humor of André. A good mix of anti-humor and humor that only he understands.

There are many Poles who work as cleaners. Perhaps quality washing equipment from Norway? I would like you to give this to my aunt. Today they will buy presents for Dominika's uncle in Poland. But he won't be offended if I bring cabbage from Norway as a gift?

He gets use to it. Dominika and her family have holidayed in Poland. But it's her first time with a mate. It feels very strange to be with André. He's a friend who appreciates that kind of thing. I am quite excited to meet Dominika's family.

She doesn't talk much about her roots. I think Poland is a boring country. I don't think that much happens there.

Moja ulubiona chekolada. Polish has 70% consonants. It is a challenge to achieve something that can be pronounced. It feels like speaking gibberish. Dominika's uncle lives in Miedzyzdroje. The city lies along the Baltic Sea and has 6,000 inhabitants.

In the summer, the number multiplies when Polish and German bathers arrive. The city is a well-known spa destination, and there are ferries to Copenhagen and Ystad. Now it's dinner at Dominika's uncle and aunt's. Hello. Hello, little Dominika.

In the Polish way ... Hello, little Dominika. I see the cat is on the table. There is tradition here. Good evening. Marian. Others. Moja ulubiona chekolada. Thank you very much! Just before I was going in to see them, I stood outside and made a speech.

I am very bad at languages. Now comes the difficult part...Norweska kapusta. It's not possible... It looks like its Polish twin. Oh no! It is Norwegian. He-he-he. Cabbage, yes ... They didn't get angry.

Uncle means a lot to me. He is ... The one, apart from my mother and my brother, who is closest to me. He asks if we have klina. Say yes. He messes with me a lot.

Ordinary people tend to kiss in Poland. But in some situations you shouldn't kiss. He says that it is generally allowed to kline in Poland. It is allowed. André and I met in Mysen when I was 14 and he was 15. I was very much an outsider in Mysen. Has a special upbringing and background.

André and I became friends over a picture of asparagus beans. The difference made us known. How do you think it tastes? There was a lot of attention. Very good. It's not that far from Norwegian food.

There are three colours: beige, brown and light brown. Always. It doesn't look appetizing, but it's incredibly good. And much more flavor than in Norwegian food. Poles think Norwegian food is boring. They had some horrible mushrooms that were a complete crisis, as it were.

I think it was whole mushrooms in vinegar. It tastes very vinegary. Do you think this is good? Yes, it's my favorite. It's good that André says what he thinks. The food we were served was very 50-50. Or what to say? 20-80, to be nice.

Good and strong! I can't stand anything. It's a shame. I am from Mysen. I got the one that was around 40%. André got 80. It's dope. Dominika can stand it more than me. My little sister tolerates more. I get drunk quickly. Have a lot of fun.

Pocket knife, pocket knife I am called here in town, by people who know the truth. I don't know, I don't know the text further...

After dinner, Dominika will take André to disco polo in the neighboring town. Disco polo is inspired by Eurodance and seasoned with Polish folk music.

I thought: So many people are having so much fun to this damn music! It's full of blood-harry Poles having fun to extremely tacky, very catchy Polish music. People were very happy. Everyone thought it was fun, everyone danced. There was a good atmosphere. You were happy to be there.

What do you think of disco polo? I would rather call it Polish dance. Disco polo is from the 90s. Polish dance is what we play here now. It differs from music from the 90s because it is more similar to modern music. The music has Polish lyrics. While the melody is danceable and at least as good as in the West.

We drank the same amount. But I endured much more. When we got to the disco polo place, I was very sober. It wasn't him. I had to drink to bear being there. They weren't trying to be cool. It was pretty cool. Everyone thinks tacky music is catchy. But not everyone will admit it.

People enjoy themselves and have no inhibitions. If you get drunk in Oslo, go to Angst or something on Youngstorget, people are very careful and take care of their appearance. But here they hitch a ride. This is a genre that people don't dare admit they like. But still, the genre is alive and well. I like that.

That's the music genre I remember as Poland. Poland for me.

Disco polo, my god! The Poles have a way of partying that is damn genuine! And I have been with Dominika's family. Domi's uncle: down-to-earth and pleasant type. And we are going to Catholic church tomorrow. Drunk and damn! Good night!

We are going to a service in a Catholic church. Or fair, as it is called. How do you feel? Starting to recover. Straight from disco polo to church service? From sin to forgiveness.

As a child, my brother and I had some of the best fits of laughter in church. Because you have to sit and shut up. But can't do it, because someone sings falsely, a priest stands and polishes silver ... Holds up a wafer. Everything is strange. Extremely different from what I am used to from growing up in a Pentecostal church.

There it is a plus to let loose and be crazy. Shaking the floor, speaking in tongues ... While this was decorative and pretty. Everyone gets up and sits down at the same time. I am actually baptized in this church. Although I am not religious. Haven't been in a long time.

I wasn't, but was forced to go to church. I said to my mother: You know, I don't believe this. Åssen did she take it? Not good. It was not allowed to talk about. I have been a Christian most of my life. Until I was 18. But from the Pentecostal church.

I kind of stopped believing in one thing and one thing, from the time I was ... Say from 14-15 to 18. Then I gave up one thing and one thing. What was the first thing you stopped believing in? At some point, you get science education at school.

And then you realize that the earth is not 6,000 years old, as we are indoctrinated.

Back at the hotel after day 2. Went straight to Catholic mass. I got halo after that. Tomorrow I will be a migrant worker in Poland.

What do you think it will be like to work in Poland? I think it will be good. The salary is not everything. Your uncle owns the company. I guess most people know English.

Dominika's uncle runs a construction company. Now an old house is to be renovated. André's partner is called Georg and speaks a little English. What about a helmet? Do you use at home? Helmets are worn on construction sites, not here.

Shouldn't you be wearing a face mask? I have a mask in the car. He will have lung problems within six months. There's a lot of dust here. You get a lot of plaster in your lungs. Work, work, work. Obviously I argued too much about HSE. In the end I was just told to work.

It's kind of funny that André has been at it for ten minutes, and is already tired and starting to get angry.

André, this one is for you. Thanks. Now, what do you think? Did you rip all that? We split down the middle. You can see that he has come much further. I've never seen André like that. And I'm unlikely to see that again.

Georg was super macho, and of course he practiced martial arts. So then I thought it would be fun if he could show me something. But then he became super shy. You promised to show me some jiu-jitsu moves. Now? Oi ... Okay, then. Then I told you that I was rapping.

We agreed that I would rap in Norwegian and he would show me martial arts. The car is at Vesteng, the sound at Måsan. Rolling around in a Volvo with 96 in the bag. Don't party nearly enough, don't play loud enough before they complain from Vestereng and Høytorp. Hanging out at Mørstad, hanging out at Trøgstad... Did you like it? Good!

I think he thought André was very special. "What kind of man is this?"

Pardon. You hit my helmet in the face. You are good. He seemed like a really nice guy. He was a Mysen type. Virka ... But he had an engineering degree. It is not typical Mysen. But he had a typical Mysen job.

When I'm on holiday, I tend to buy the ugliest card I can find. Here is a postcard with amber. Look there, then. This is absolutely beautiful! The ugliest postcard I've seen. There is a stone inside! There is an even uglier one. My name should be here. There! Key ring with my name.

I feel very Norwegian. Absolutely. I'm Norwegian. The feeling of home in Poland became less with each and every year we lived in Norway. But I am very happy to go there to visit my family. And proud to be from Poland.

Hei. Velkommen til det kongelige bibliotek. Det blir vel spennende å se hva vi kan finne ut om familien Lelïenhof. Absolutt. Vi er veldig spent. Her er en tegning av hvordan de fraktet slavene.

Som vi ser, lå de stuet sammen. På dette skipet var det rundt 500. Jeg forstår ikke hvordan folk kan være så grusomme og hjerteløse.

Og på denne lista står alle Lelïenhofene.

Her har vi den eldste i familierekka. Det er Magdalena Martha, født i 1794 eller 1800.

Hvis vi regner med Martha, har vi sju Lelïenhof-generasjoner. Den eldste er Martha Magdalena.

Hallo!

Fem grader nord. Og 56 grader vest.

Ser dere under den blomsten der? Ja. Der var det en gravplass. Ingen har klart å finne den før. Så dette er første gang noen har funnet den, etter hundre år. Hvis man graver her, vil man finne ... Skjeletter.

Har dere funnet mer? Dette er litt av grunnmuren. Det kan ha vært fabrikken. Eller kanskje et hus på plantasjen. Hva produserte de på plantasjen? Sukker. Hvor mange arbeidet her? 1900 slaver.

Fant du den? Dette er en gammel vanntank. De har bare fjernet steinene.

Hallo!

Hei, Eric! Hallo. Hvordan står det til? Marcel. Hei. Hvordan står det til?

Disse blomstene er fra Marcel og meg. Hvil i fred.

"En merkelig hendelse. En Nassoulaan-beboer ble i går kveld ..."

"... drepte for et år siden sin elskerinne. Etterpå tok han livet sitt."

Velkommen. Dette er den eldste bygningen her. Den eneste fra den gangen. Er den fortsatt i bruk? Ja. Det er fortsatt pasienter der. Men det er planer om å slutte med det. På den tiden ble de isolert fra samfunnet. De gikk i tvangstrøye.

Aggresjonen måtte stagges, så det ble ro, og man ikke var til bry for samfunnet. Ingen behandling? Nei. Perioden han var her, var før ting ble mer marginalisert. Men han døde vel ikke her? Jo.

Så her er navnene. Juliana Edwardina Plett. Det er Marcels farmor. Hun bodde i Mindhop nr. 2. Det burde være her. Lelïenhof.

Vi blir med ham til moren hans. Hun er gammel og født og oppvokst her. Hva tror du? Jeg tror vi finner noe. Jeg har det på følelsen.

Bestefaren min het Isidore Max Wilhelm Lelïenhof. Lelïenhof ... Max Wilhelm Lelïenhof. Han vet jeg ikke hvem er, nei.

Takk, frue.

Orlando Lelïenhof. Var Isidore faren din? Ja.

Min mor, Juliana Plett ...

Giftet de seg i kirken her? Ja.
