<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

How are you? Just good. What are you going to do? We thought of the concentration camps. You know who Hitler was? He with the mustache that always screamed. He killed Jews. People claim all kinds of things, but we want to see it with our own eyes.

Then we have a little more insight.

ON THE AWAY COURSE

Can't we eat here then? Join us instead.

Can I have two hamburgers? No, two kebabs with chicken. And a salad without meat. Dressing? No thanks. Have you had a job? Yes, at H & M, but it wasn't easy. They allow hijab, but some customers refused to talk to me. Is it true? Yes.

That's how it is on the football pitch too. They see I'm Moroccan and shout. Yeah right. It's nothing special. Are you coming to the game? When is it? Saturday eight thirty. Then it doesn't work. You can't come? A kebab with chicken and a coke.

I'm looking through the highlights now. No, just forget it! Now you anticipate it. No, Nishan. That's right. I'm going to be a soccer player. Have you turned up the speed? I can't help you being quick.

We're going to watch "The Voice" tonight. Okay, it'll be fine. Good bye.

Judge You are getting ready now. We'll see how it goes. The referee has to cope with the pressure. Players can get quite frustrated. The first time I was stressed. Now I'm used to it. Number 3, Silas Lucas.

Number 23, Léonin. Number 30, Matthew. See you out on the pitch!

We take this side. Okay, you go there.

Come on! Good! Captain! Just hang up the shirts. Yes.

I hope a lot of people will come. El Atmani, Souleymane. There. Okay, you can just go inside. Thank you.

Do you see her in the middle there? She is a politician. Unclex, yes. She knows Milquet. Today we will hold an information meeting about the Palestine conflict. There has been an unpleasant shift in Israeli society.

Now the extreme right is in power. Of course, we must distance ourselves from that. How does the Jewish community in Belgium view the conflict?

It is very difficult for Jews around the world not to be drawn into Israel's politics. More and more people are speaking out and expressing dissatisfaction with the policy. They say we must not interfere. They will take care of it themselves.

It is behind the front seat. Come on! Just slide it on. It looked like there were more Arabs than Jews there. How do you know who is Jewish? You can see that. It is easy to pick out the Arabs. This doesn't work.

Are you doing well? Yes. I just can't wait to beat you in FIFA. We will now have to look at that.

The living room is straight ahead. Just walk in. I haven't played yet. Just wait! It's 3-0 at the break. Hey boys. How are you? Who leads? Ahmed.

What are you doing? It's the lever! How was the meeting? What did they say? They explained the history behind the Palestine conflict. Did you say something? Yes, I asked a question. I asked how Jews in Belgium view the conflict.

And if there was anything we did beyond demonstrating. She said we had to keep pressuring the government. Come on! Good! He is so good. Yes, Nishan. I had forgotten how good he was.

He will be. We have seen him play. He lived here, too. Yes, that's right. He used to play here in the neighborhood. And there was a goal! Do not blame me! I said it was just as difficult for me.

Put the things away. The bags on the table! We're not just going to Auschwitz. We are going to Kraków in Poland. You get to meet young people from here with a different background. They are from the group UEJB, which stands for ... Help me a little. The Student Organization of Belgian Jews.

It will be a good opportunity to find out what we have in common. What do you think it is, then? After all, we are all human, and we believe in God.

Can we wash before the prayer? Relax. It will be alright. We have to bring clothes we can pray in.

I have the ticket. Great! Grab a brochure and get on the bus. You are a system man. Do not wake those who sleep. And at least not us.

I'll talk to him. Was it you who sang? Are you going to sign up for "The Voice"? No. What does the family say about you taking this trip? They think it's good. They said I should go. I'm interested in it, and I think they're good.

The Holocaust was not far away. It was here with us. It's not just their story. It's ours too. We must remember that the Holocaust is part of everyone's history.

where is my bag "My suitcase" is called it. There is a shower in the room next to it. It's pretty spartan.

God be praised, we say. Alcohol is forbidden in our religion. I think it's better that way. It's not about banning everything, but it does more damage. In Judaism, we drink wine on religious holidays.

At Passover, when we celebrate the exodus from Egypt, we drink a glass of wine as part of the tradition. But not because of religion. Yes, it is part of the ritual. Do men and women sit separately? It depends on the synagogue. There are different directions.

It is in that direction.

It's midnight, but you're living life like you're at a football match. Lie down now. You took longer than a girl! It took forever. Honestly! I showered for three minutes. No, it was six. Half past half past six.

I'm not one to cry, but it's a lot to take in. The entrance with the gloomy motto is over there. It is very bestial. Arbeit macht frei. This means that if you work, you get time off.

Now we're going to the gas chambers. I have so many questions. No, I'm sure it was 1.1 million. But then it says 25,000. The first attempt to kill prisoners with gas lasted two days.

Once the Nazis had calculated how much was needed, it took fifteen minutes to kill up to two thousand at once. Are you going to ask? I need to do some research first. I compare what they say. Here, the family of my grandmother, Rosalie, was murdered.

The father Ephraim Vilavski, the mother Sylvia Blumbaum, and the older sister Sarah. The same thing happened to all Jewish families in the occupied countries. Now anti-Semitism is again on the rise.

Such events take place all over Europe, and Jews are threatened with their lives. To come here, where humanity has weathered, is to be a fellow human being. They did not win. They never do. We are still here.

2 months later

Hi Jonathan. Let me go. How are you? Long time no see! Are you doing well at school? Well, it works in a way. Are you still a judge? Yes. We were supposed to play football together. Yes, there will be a tournament. You can come and play with us. That's OK.

I am happy to be here with you. Prejudice occurs when we don't know each other. They develop into fear and hatred. We had prejudices and were distrustful and afraid, but the meeting was positive. You were on the bus, and it shows that the skeptics are wrong.

You are real people. Your parents and teachers can be proud of you.

My name is Jonathan. Hello. Are you going to judge? No, I'm going to play. Hello, my name is Jonathan. Shall we change? Yes, come on.

You have the white one. You are a goalkeeper. You can start with the ball. We have to go through the rules. We said three ... Three or something! We shoot from there without speeding up. Just kick the ball. May the best win! Good luck! Are they ready, right? Come on guys!

Go to! Follow him! Good! Was it inside? Yes.

Come on! Do not try to do it on your own.

Thank you for the match! You played well! Ibrahimovic. What a beast! He even plays. That is unbelievable. What is the position? Do not know. He almost didn't run into you!

You almost split me in two! Are you kidding me, Zack? No, he wasn't into you. You almost passed out. Yes. Who did you travel with? The students from UEJB. Sainte-Famille was also involved. It was a nice trip. Quite emotional.

At least we could talk about football. And everything else. I remember there was a demonstration in 2009. They claimed to support the Palestinians. But it ended with them shouting "kill the Jews" here in Brussels. People confuse the Jews

with what is happening in Israel. We have to work on that. That kind of language is starting to show itself in actions. That's how it starts. There is a lot of racism going on. "You fucking Arab" and stuff like that.

You meet it on the football field? Yes, from the players. Is it true? It ended in a fight at Charleroi. Punish? Yes, it's a penalty kick. What an idiot! You play football with all kinds of people. When we were called "damn Jews",

they too were enraged. It happens that they are called that too, and then they reacted in the same way. There was one who said, "You don't shave, you fucking Arab." Thats true. I had just started the match. It was my third match. We're having a ceremony. You're welcome to join. It commemorates the Holocaust.

We read out the names of everyone who was deported from Belgium. There are over 25,000 names. It lasts a whole day. You can come and read. It is an interesting experience.

He's the only one who doesn't have a bag with him. Let him sit in front. He is so tall.

On 11 August 1942, 999 people were deported. We will read out the names of the 996 who were brutally killed by the Nazis. Our memories are your memories. Only three survived. Calfus, Max. 35 years. Graf, Hermann. 28 years. Kuchermann, Shlama. 16 years.

Lenzig, Saul. 36 years. Kaplan, Bernard. 17 years. Kaplan, Alphonse. 18 years.

column2:
Hei. Å, hei! Kjenner du Souleymane? Jeg heter Gaëlle. Souleymane går på Sainte-Famille. Vi var i Polen sammen. Nettopp. I november. Og nå er han kommet for å lese. Så bra! Det jødiske samfunnet er veldig takkenemlig.

Ja, det er enstemmig. Solski, Jacques. 18 år. Hofferman, Mojek David. 19 år. Chojnacki, Shiwer. 17 år. Redlich, Henla Laia. 48 år.

Redlich, Herman. 15 år. Redlich, Adolf. 11 år. Ickowicz, Albert. 16 år. Ickowicz, Edith. 19 år. Zirpro, Herzlick. 23 år. Baczynski, Sirla. 25 år. Klaj, Herz. 17 år. Zinnamon, Israel. 30 år. Marton, Maurice. 29 år.

Krebus, Emilia. 16 år. Liebson, Sarah. 16 år. Krajdicyk, Irma. 22 år. Najman, Jankiel. 28 år. Kattner, Felix. 21 år. Savelen, Henka. 16 år. Figerhut, Ruud. 16 år. Zuckerbrot, Samuel Joseph. 18 år.
column3:
Hello. Oh, hey! Do you know Souleymane? My name is Gaëlle. Souleymane attends Sainte-Famille. We were in Poland together. Exactly. In November. And now he has come to read. So good! The Jewish community is very grateful.

Yes, it is unanimous. Solski, Jacques. 18 years. Hofferman, Mojek David. 19 years. Chojnacki, Shiwer. 17 years. Redlich, Henla Laia. 48 years.

Redlich, Herman. 15 years. Redlich, Adolf. 11 years. Ickowicz, Albert. 16 years. Ickowicz, Edith. 19 years. Zirpro, Herzlick. 23 years. Baczynski, Sirla. 25 years. All right, Herz. 17 years. Zinnamon, Israel. 30 years. Marton, Maurice. 29 years.

Krebus, Emilia. 16 years. Liebson, Sarah. 16 years. Krajdicyk, Irma. 22 years. Najman, Jankiel. 28 years. Kattner, Felix. 21 years. Savelen, Henka. 16 years. Figherhut, Ruud. 16 years. Zuckerbrot, Samuel Joseph. 18 years.

Da jeg var i Nigeria, sa de at jeg brøt loven. De sa at jeg ville få 14 år i fengsel. Det taklet jeg ikke, så jeg måtte dra fra Nigeria. Jeg forlot onkelen min og familien hans.

Da jeg dro. De hadde et vitne og bevis da de tok meg. De tok meg. Underveis i prosessen rømte jeg.

Hvordan går det? Bra. Det er godt å se deg igjen. Du smiler alltid. Når fikk du papiret? Mandag. Da jeg fikk avslag, klarte jeg ikke å smile.

Jeg ville så gjerne bli. Jeg trodde jeg hadde gitt alt. Denne institusjonen kan forandre livet ditt. Og ødelegge det. Etter ett år ble jeg innkalt til et tredje intervju. Jeg fikk også avslag. Kan du snakke for ham når han anker?

Har du dokumenter som bevis? Ja, politiet har fått alt. Jeg kom til Zagreb for å skaffe advokat. Det beste er en kvinnelig advokat. En eldre, kvinnelig advokat. Jeg kan anbefale noen, men da må du si fra.

Det skal jeg. Det eneste som kan glede meg nå, er å få spille for FC Zagreb igjen. Jeg elsker fotball.

Har noen forklart hvorfor du fikk avslag? Nei. Det første problemet jeg ser ... Du oppga et annet navn i den første søknaden.

Ja, jeg oppga et annet navn, og jeg sa at jeg var fra Somalia. Jeg forklarte hvorfor. Hadde jeg sagt at jeg var fra Nigeria, ville jeg blitt deportert. Jeg søkte asyl og havnet på et mottak. Jeg ga dem alt dette. De ba om mer bevis. Jeg ga dem dette. Jeg eier et firma i Nigeria.

Dette er beviset. Dette er firmaet mitt. Ebuka Matthew Okeke. Din onkel eller far? Det er mitt navn. Matthew er min fars navn. Ja vel. Okeke er etternavnet mitt. Jeg har bare skummet gjennom saken.

Det er kjent at homofile ikke er trygge i Nigeria. Vi bør kanskje fokusere på det. Jeg syns du bør legge vekt på din homofile legning. Om mulig bør du skaffe dokumenter fra Nigeria.

Jeg har ikke familie i Nigeria. Det sa jeg jo. Etter intervjuet med NOVA TV, sendte noen opptaket til Nigeria. De drepte onkelen min. Når var det? I år? Ja, i 2015. Etter mitt tredje intervju. Jeg fortalte ham det. Jeg er sikker på at han ikke tok det med.

En ung nigerianers traumatiske historie. Jeg er homofil. Homofile i Nigeria får 15 år i fengsel. Etter intervjuet med NOVA TV, drepte de onkelen min og la en lapp på brystet hans.

"Gi oss den homofile Prince Ebuka Okeke, som skjemmer ut Nigeria," "ellers dreper vi resten av familien." Drepte de onkelen din? Ja. På grunn av meg. På grunn av det intervjuet? Ja. De la igjen lapp.

Se på dette bildet. Jeg ga ham dette. Søsteren min ble knivstukket. Er dette søsteren din? Ja. Jeg ga ham bildet. Er det trygt for meg i Nigeria nå? Nei. Politiet vet at du er homofil. Det visste de før dette også. Det vil hjelpe med dødsattest. For søsteren din og onkelen din.

Og prøv å forklare at dette skjedde fordi de oppdaget at du er homofil.

Gi meg styrke til å fortsette kampen. Denne børen er for tung for meg. Hjelp meg med å bli her i Kroatia. Jeg elsker dette landet. Jesus, hør min bønn. Plasser meg her i Kroatia, og legg Kroatia i Jesu hender.

Jeg er katolikk, og jeg tror på Gud. Jeg tror på Jesus Kristus. Men dette blir for mye for meg. De tok oss med hit til Kutina. Vi er alene. Ingen vi kan snakke med, ingen aktiviteter. Ingen steder å dra. Fra mottaket til sentrum tar det 45 minutter.

Det er langt å gå. I Zagreb møter man folk. Man får nye venner. Man møter folk man kan spille med og snakke med. Da har man noe å gjøre. Her i Kutina er det ingenting.

Folk som har kjent meg før, spør om det virkelig er meg. Jeg vet ikke hva jeg skal gjøre. Jeg vet ikke hvor jeg skal dra. Kanskje jeg må komme meg på et tog og dra til et annet sted.

Alle har sin egen historie. Jeg vet bare om meg selv, og jeg forteller sannheten.

Hva har skjedd siden sist? Har du hatt kontakt med familie eller venner i Nigeria? Sist fortalte jeg at de fleste i familien min døde på grunn av ... Problemet mitt. Kan du be en venn skaffe dokumentene vi trenger? Det vil komme veldig godt med.

Jeg kan bare be min venn om å møte advokaten. Min venn kan ikke skaffe dokumentene. I Nigeria utstedes ikke dokumenter på samme måte som her i Europa. Så han eller hun kan ikke gå til politiet eller retten og be om kopier? Nei. Hva er så vanskelig?

Å skaffe dokumentene er ikke lett fordi man må blottlegge seg. Da kommer myndighetene til å angripe. Da blir man overvåket. Jeg vil ikke at noen skal dø. Så mange har dødd. Jeg har ingen bror, søster, mor, far eller noen familie.

Det er bare meg. Onkelen min er død. Barna hans er døde på grunn av meg. Hvorfor skal jeg blande inn vennene mine? Det er ikke ... Vær god mot deg selv. Og tålmodig. Det er det beste rådet jeg kan gi deg.

Jeg har vært i Kroatia i to år nå. Uten å gå. Jeg bare spiser og sover. Ingen aktiviteter. Bare mat og søvn. Tenk deg det. Det er ikke bra.

Prince Ebuka. Hvordan har du det? Hvordan går det med deg? Jeg sov da dere ringte. Sover du til klokka ni? Tolv. Du sier at du bare spiser og sover. Jeg spiser og sover, spiser og sover.

Det er fælt. Bare Gud vet. Jeg overlever fordi Gud vil. Ikke bli frustrert av dette. Det hjelper ikke å være frustrert. Det verste er å være deprimert. Ikke bli deprimert. Prøv å leve. Jeg forstår deg. Jeg har vært gjennom det, men det var annerledes i Zagreb.

I Zagreb kan man gå ut og møte folk. Det kan man ikke her. Jeg tenkte at jeg kan vente til mai. Så begynner jeg hos dere. Mars, unnskyld. Hvis du ikke trener på to-tre måneder, vil du slite med å spille fotball igjen.

Du blir lett skadet, og dessuten vil du ikke være i form. Dette er vanskeligere enn jeg trodde. Denne ballen er til deg. Den forandrer ingenting, men den er en del av å være fotballspiller. Den gir deg noe å holde fast i. Tusen takk.

Kutinas ungdomsorganisasjon Charlie? Jeg har en asylsøker her. Han ble flyttet til Kutina fra mottaket i Porin. I Zagreb spilte han fotball for et lag der. Han har vært her alene i tre måneder uten noe å gjøre.

Han vil gjerne trene, så jeg lurer på om han kan få trene med dere? Kan dere møte ham i dag eller i morgen? Klokka to? Du møter ham om to timer. Da får du se klubben, banen og alt.

Er det greit? Ja. Tusen takk. Jeg er klar. Hva syns dere?

Hei. Jeg er tidlig ute. Bedre enn å være for sen. Du må ha vært midtbanespiller? Ja. Jeg ser det på fotarbeidet. Flott.

Alle asylsøkere måtte forlate Zagreb, så han må bo i Kutina nå. Da jeg besøkte ham, gjorde han ingenting. Han sov bare. Jeg vet ikke hvordan jeg kan hjelpe ham. Sport og fotball fører folk sammen. Det er poenget. Du kan ringe meg hver dag. Helt i orden.

Du skal få treningstidene. Vi trener hver dag klokka seks. Du skal få telefonnummeret mitt. Han får mobilnummeret mitt. Kan du skrive det ned for ham? Du er spiss, hva?

Si til ham at ørepynt ikke er tillatt på trening.

Vi ses, Charlie. Vi ses, Charlie. Jeg håper å få gode nyheter. Om at du har scoret et fantastisk mål. Jeg tenker bare på at du benket meg.

Da jeg var ung ... Da jeg var 14 år, drømte jeg om å bli fotballspiller. I dag er jeg i Kroatia uten noen framtidsdrøm. Jeg vet ikke hva som vil skje. Drømmen er fotball, men man blir ikke fotballspiller over natta. Nå får jeg se. Jeg vet ikke om jeg kan oppfylle drømmen.

Hallo. Hvordan har du det? Bra. Og du? Veldig bra. Er du klar til å trene? Ja. Ikke noe problem. Guttene venter.

Jeg har ikke sko eller drakt. Ikke noe problem. Bli med meg. Kom igjen, Mario. I dag har vi en ny spiller med oss. Prince. Prince. Takk. La meg presentere en ny spiller.

Han er ikke på laget, men ba om å få trene med oss. Prince er ... Fra Kamerun, ikke sant? Velkommen. Nigeria. Unnskyld! Fra Nigeria. Velkommen. Velkommen skal du være. Prøv disse.

Størrelse 44.

Disse burde passe.

Drible. Løft blikket! Gutter, dere kan tøye ut. Prince! Treningen er over. Mata har bil. Du kan bli med ham. Mata, rekk opp hånden. Jeg føler meg som et nytt menneske. Uten stress.

Jeg tenker ikke på at jeg fikk avslag. Glem at jeg søker asyl. De er vennlige. Særlig treneren. Morsom mann. Jeg elsket å spille her. Å, hofta mi ...

Otokú."Han er død." Dette er menneskeblod. De har ikke noe politi som kan redde dem. På videoen ser du at det står en politimann der. Han gjorde ingenting. Ingenting. Hvis politimannen ba dem slutte, ville de drept ham også.

Kroatia sender meg dit for å bli drept. Sender meg i graven. Jeg så døden. Ikke bare som vitne. Jeg opplevde død. Jeg lå i koma i tre dager etter å ha fått bank. Så jeg var ikke bare vitne. Jeg opplevde det. Du spurte om jeg har sett døden. Det har jeg.

Jeg unnslapp døden. Ikke én eller to ganger. Tre ganger. I Afrika. I Nigeria. Ikke Afrika, Nigeria.

Jeg vet ikke hva jeg skal si. Hva ... Tyrkia? Jeg får lyst til å slå deg! Ja, jeg var i Tyrkia. Du sa Sveits og Tyskland! Jeg sa til dem at jeg var i Tyrkia.

Vi gikk ikke utendørs. Vi ble sendt til Tyrkia, og så videre til Tyskland. Greit. Var det noe annet? Det gjorde at hun ikke tror på deg.

Greit. Gjort er gjort. Vi må vente på avgjørelsen. Så snart jeg får den, hører du fra meg. Ikke noe problem. Det er greit. Jeg blir ikke sjokkert neste gang. Ikke etter det første avslaget.

When I was in Nigeria, they said I broke the law. They said I would get 14 years in prison. I couldn't handle that, so I had to leave Nigeria. I left my uncle and his family.

When I left. They had a witness and evidence when they took me. They took me. During the process I escaped.

How are you? Good. It's good to see you again. You always smile. When did you get the paper? Monday. When I was rejected, I couldn't help but smile.

I would so love to stay. I thought I had given it my all. This institution can change your life. And destroy it. After one year, I was called for a third interview. I was also rejected. Can you speak for him when he appeals?

Do you have documents as proof? Yes, the police have got everything. I came to Zagreb to get a lawyer. The best is a female lawyer. An older, female lawyer. I can recommend someone, but then you have to say no.

I will. The only thing that can make me happy now is to play for FC Zagreb again. I love football.

Has anyone explained why you were rejected? No. The first problem I see ... You provided a different name in the first application.

Yes, I gave a different name and I said I was from Somalia. I explained why. If I had said I was from Nigeria, I would have been deported. I applied for asylum and ended up in a reception. I gave them all this. They asked for more evidence. I gave them this. I own a company in Nigeria.

This is the proof. This is my company. Ebuka Matthew Okeke. Your uncle or father? That's my name. Matthew is my father's name. Oh well. Okeke is my surname. I just skimmed through the matter.

It is known that gays are not safe in Nigeria. Maybe we should focus on that. I think you should emphasize your gay orientation. If possible, you should obtain documents from Nigeria.

I have no family in Nigeria. That's what I said. After the interview with NOVA TV, someone sent the recording to Nigeria. They killed my uncle. When was it? This year? Yes, in 2015. After my third interview. I told him that. I'm sure he didn't bring it.

The traumatic story of a young Nigerian. I am homosexual. Homosexuals in Nigeria get 15 years in prison. After the interview with NOVA TV, they killed my uncle and put a note on his chest.

"Give us the gay Prince Ebuka Okeke, who disgraces Nigeria," "or we will kill the rest of the family." Did they kill your uncle? Yes. Because of me. Because of that interview? Yes. They left a note.

Look at this picture. I gave him this. My sister was stabbed. Is this your sister? Yes. I gave him the picture. Is it safe for me in Nigeria now? No. The police know you're gay. They knew that before this too. It will help with the death certificate. For your sister and your uncle.

And try to explain that this happened because they discovered that you are gay.

Give me strength to continue the fight. This bag is too heavy for me. Help me stay here in Croatia. I love this country. Jesus, hear my prayer. Place me here in Croatia, and place Croatia in the hands of Jesus.

I am Catholic and I believe in God. I believe in Jesus Christ. But this is too much for me. They took us here to Kutina. We are alone. No one to talk to, no activities. Nowhere to go. It takes 45 minutes from the reception to the city centre.

There is a long way to go. In Zagreb you meet people. You make new friends. You meet people you can play with and talk to. Then you have something to do. Here in Kutina there is nothing.

People who have known me before ask if it's really me. I do not know what to do. I don't know where to go. Maybe I need to get on a train and go somewhere else.

Everyone has their own story. I only know about myself and I tell the truth.

What has happened since last time? Have you had contact with family or friends in Nigeria? Last time I told you that most of my family died because of... My problem. Can you ask a friend to get the documents we need? It will come in very handy.

I can only ask my friend to meet the lawyer. My friend cannot obtain the documents. In Nigeria, documents are not issued in the same way as here in Europe. So he or she can't go to the police or court and ask for copies? No. What is so difficult?

Obtaining the documents is not easy because you have to expose yourself. Then the authorities will attack. Then you will be monitored. I don't want anyone to die. So many have died. I have no brother, sister, mother, father or any family.

It's just me. My uncle is dead. His children are dead because of me. Why should I involve my friends? It's not ... Be kind to yourself. And patient. That's the best advice I can give you.

I have been in Croatia for two years now. Without going. I just eat and sleep. No activities. Just food and sleep. Imagine that. It is not good.

Prince Ebuka. How are you? How are you? I was asleep when you called. Do you sleep until nine o'clock? Twelve. You say you just eat and sleep. I eat and sleep, eat and sleep.

It's awful. Only God knows. I survive because God wills. Don't be frustrated by this. It doesn't help to be frustrated. The worst thing is being depressed. Don't get depressed. Try to live. I understand you. I've been through it, but it was different in Zagreb.

In Zagreb you can go out and meet people. You can't do that here. I thought I can wait until May. Then I'll start with you. Mars, I'm sorry. If you don't train for two or three months, you will struggle to play football again.

You get injured easily, and besides, you won't be in shape. This is harder than I thought. This ball is for you. It doesn't change anything, but it's part of being a footballer. It gives you something to hold on to. Thank you very much.

Kutina's youth organization Charlie? I have an asylum seeker here. He was moved to Kutina from the reception in Porin. In Zagreb, he played football for a team there. He has been here alone for three months with nothing to do.

He would like to train, so I wonder if he can train with you? Can you meet him today or tomorrow? At two o'clock? You will meet him in two hours. Then you get to see the club, the pitch and everything.

It is okay? Yes. Thank you very much. I'm ready. What do you think?

Hello. I'm early. Better than being late. You must have been a midfielder? Yes. I see it in the footwork. Great.

All asylum seekers had to leave Zagreb, so he has to live in Kutina now. When I visited him, he did nothing. He just slept. I don't know how to help him. Sport and football bring people together. That's the point. You can call me every day. All right.

You will get the training times. We train every day at six o'clock. You will get my phone number. He gets my mobile number. Can you write it down for him? You're sharp, huh?

Tell him that earrings are not allowed in training.

See you, Charlie. See you, Charlie. I hope to get good news. That you have scored a fantastic goal. I'm just thinking about you benching me.

When I was young... When I was 14, I dreamed of becoming a footballer. Today I am in Croatia without any future dreams. I don't know what will happen. The dream is football, but you don't become a footballer overnight. Now I'll see. I don't know if I can fulfill my dream.

Hello. How are you? Good. And you? Very good. Are you ready to train? Yes. No problem. The boys are waiting.

I don't have shoes or a suit. No problem. Come with me. Come on, Mario. Today we have a new player with us. Prince. Prince. Thanks. Let me introduce a new player.

He is not on the team, but asked to train with us. Prince is... From Cameroon, right? Welcome. Nigeria. Pardon! From Nigeria. Welcome. Welcome you shall be. Try these.

Size 44.

These should fit.

Dribble. Look up! Guys, you can stretch. Prince! Training is over. Mata has a car. You can join him. Feed, raise your hand. I feel like a new person. Without stress.

I don't think about the fact that I was rejected. Forget that I am seeking asylum. They are friendly. Especially the coach. Funny man. I loved playing here. Oh, my hip...

Otokú."He is dead." This is human blood. They have no police to save them. In the video you see that there is a policeman there. He did nothing. Nothing. If the policeman told them to stop, they would kill him too.

Croatia is sending me there to be killed. Sends me to the grave. I saw death. Not just as a witness. I experienced death. I was in a coma for three days after being knocked down. So I wasn't just a witness. I experienced it. You asked if I have seen death. I have.

I escaped death. Not once or twice. Three times. In Africa. In Nigeria. Not Africa, Nigeria.

I do not know what to say. What...Turkey? Makes me want to punch you! Yes, I was in Turkey. You said Switzerland and Germany! I told them I was in Turkey.

We didn't go outdoors. We were sent to Turkey, and then to Germany. Right. Was it something else? It made her not believe in you.

Right. Done is done. We have to wait for the decision. As soon as I get it, you will hear from me. No problem. It is okay. I won't be shocked next time. Not after the first rejection.

column2:
<|nocaptions|>

<|nocaptions|>

Unnskyld meg, jeg kan ikke reise meg fordi ...

Jeg ble veldig lykkelig for dette. Tusen takk for at jeg fikk komme.

Jeg finner ikke ord ... Det gjør ikke jeg heller. Men du er ikke bra? Beina er dårlige, og hoftene også.

Jeg er veldig stolt over å være halvt tyrkisk. Jeg har alltid sagt at jeg er halvt tyrkisk. Ingen har trodd meg, med blå øyne og blondt hår.

Denne er også til deg.

I nattklubben. I 1966. Ja. Jeg er født i 1967.

Brått ble hele min verden forandret.

Det var helt utrolig for oss. Jeg likte henne veldig godt. Hun er varm, og jeg tror hun har mye kjærlighet. Det er tydelig at hun har lett etter faren, og at hun savnet ham. Det er fantastisk. Jeg kan fortsatt ikke tro det. Adjø.

Vi møtes snart igjen. Veldig, veldig snart.

Vi lurer på om vi kan gjøre opptak inne. Hvis dere kommer seinere, kan dere få tillatelse. Det er fare for skader nå.

Dette er utrolig! Tusen takk. Ufattelig! Jeg fatter det ikke. Dette er så merkelig.

Vi satt og spiste i går, bare vi to, så sa vi: "Tenk at vi er onkler!" De gleder seg veldig til å se dere. Jeg håper vi kan komme på besøk. Hvordan reagerte dere da faren deres fortalte om søsteren?

Det morsomme er at vennene til faren min alltid har ertet ham: "Du har sikkert en datter et sted." Faren min var en stor playboy, for å være ærlig. Faren vår, mener jeg. Jeg er glad for at familien er blitt større. Det er veldig hyggelig.

Jeg tror vi drar til basaren. Vi kan spise lunsj der. Flott! Vi kan vise deg litt rundt. Takk. Herlig.

Hva er dette? Det er godt. Tyrkisk konfekt.

Det er som pashmina. Rødt og hvitt passer sammen. Fargen er fin. Bare behold det på. Vi har allerede kjøpt det. Det kan bli kaldt. Mener dere det?

Dette er en gave fra oss. Fra Ahmed og meg. Granateplet ... Dette er også en gave. Med tulipaner i.

Er du helt utslitt? Det går fint. Hvordan går det med deg? Bra, takk. Jeg har med en gave. Det er litt opprevet her, men ... Nydelig.

Nå har du de tre jentene. Julia, Vendela, Hannah. Alle tre samlet. Vil du se det nye huset ditt? Og så rommet ditt? Ha det! Takk skal dere ha!

Er du spent? Ja, det er jeg. Vi har et nydelig hus. Velkommen. Takk for det. Se her. Jeg tror du kjenner henne. Dette er deg. De har skrevet det ut fra ... Da går vi ut. Dette er balkongen. Mellom de to fjellene er byen Marmaris, hvor vi var.

Og til høyre ... Men det ser vi ikke. Rodos er der borte og øya Symi også.

Kjære venner, jeg er lykkelig fordi jeg har funnet datteren min. Vi møttes i Amsterdam den 9. mars. Jeg tror hun liker seg sammen med vennene mine. Vi skal spise sammen. Takk for at dere er kommet, alle sammen. Takk for det! Takk, du òg, kjære.

Jeg vil også gjerne si noe. Håper jeg ikke begynner å gråte. Jeg vil takke min far for at jeg får komme hit. Det er helt fantastisk! Og alle dere som kom for å møte meg. Sirin, selvsagt. Og min bror. Hvor er han? Skål! Dette er helt fantastisk.

Jeg er blitt 45 år, og har endelig funnet andre halvdel av familien min. Fantastisk! Aldri for sent. Nå feirer vi, alle sammen! La oss spise og drikke sammen!

Jeg begynner et nytt liv. Det har virkelig forandret noe i livet mitt. Jeg er lykkelig. Jeg spør meg selv hvorfor jeg ikke har møtt henne ... Igjen og igjen spør jeg meg selv hvorfor jeg ikke har møtt henne før. Jeg har ønsket meg en datter hele livet.

Jeg sier det fordi døtre har et nærmere forhold til faren. Gutter står nærmere moren sin. Jeg tror det, ja. De er mer opptatt av moren sin enn av meg. Alt spennende i livet forteller de til moren sin. Om forelskelser og slikt. Ikke til pappa.

Jeg håpet at jeg skulle møte deg og bli kjent med deg. Da dette begynte, ante jeg ingenting. Jeg visste ikke om jeg ville få møte ham. Han kunne være død. Eller kanskje han ikke ville møte meg. Jeg kunne vært alkoholiker eller tilhørt mafiaen ... Hva som helst.

Mafia ... Ja visst, ja.

And to the right ... But we don't see that. Rhodes is over there and the island of Symi too.

Dear friends, I am happy because I have found my daughter. We met in Amsterdam on 9 March. I think she likes being with my friends. We will eat together. Thanks for coming, everyone. Thanks for that! Thank you, you too, dear.

I would also like to say something. Hope I don't start crying. I want to thank my father for letting me come here. It's absolutely fantastic! And all of you who came to meet me. Sirin, of course. And my brother. Where is he? Toast! This is absolutely fantastic.

I have turned 45, and have finally found the other half of my family. Fantastic! Never too late. Now let's celebrate, everyone! Let's eat and drink together!

I am starting a new life. It has really changed something in my life. I am happy. I ask myself why I haven't met her ... Again and again I ask myself why I haven't met her before. I have wanted a daughter all my life.

I say that because daughters have a closer relationship with their father. Boys stand closer to their mothers. I think so, yes. They are more concerned with their mother than with me. They tell their mother everything exciting in life. About falling in love and such. Not for dad.

I was hoping that I would meet you and get to know you. When this started, I had no idea. I didn't know if I would get to meet him. He could be dead. Or maybe he didn't want to meet me. I could have been an alcoholic or belonged to the mafia... Whatever.

Mafia ... Yes sure, yes.

Det er en flott overraskelse! Så vi kan bli litt overstadige. Velkommen hjem! Jeg er hjemme, ja. Det er fantastisk! Nå som du har møtt oss, Kashfa, har vi enda en overraskelse til deg. Du skal møte bestemoren din, og det er århundrets overraskelse.

Jeg er veldig glad i deg. Jeg er glad i deg. Jeg er så glad i deg. Hvorfor har du ikke sagt noe?

Vi har ikke kommet hit for å sørge og gråte, men for å hylle livet. Paul Mungarurire ... Livet hans var fylt av glede. Og vi er samlet her, spesielt av hensyn til Pauls sønn, Kashfa. Kashfa likner veldig på faren sin. Han har også den samme væremåten.

Så dette er et veldig viktig øyeblikk. Vi venter på at Kashfa skal komme fram og synge ... Gjøre noe ... Hva som helst. Jeg er sammen med alle jeg er glad i. Familien min. Og onkel, som har organisert alt dette.

Vi har kommet hit for å feire fars liv.

Han var et godt menneske. Som du. Morsom ... Ja, han var bedre. Og moren min, som mistet ... Hun mistet mannen sin. Det er en hyllest til Paul, faren min, og alle andre vi har mistet i familien.

Det er en ting til jeg gjerne vil si: Hun er den store helten i livet mitt. Hun brakte meg til et bedre liv i Norge, helt alene ... Jeg kunne ikke greid det. Alene, uten å kunne språket. Hun hadde mistet mann og familie. De beste vennene hennes var borte.

Så nå er det min tur ...

We have not come here to mourn and cry, but to celebrate life. Paul Mungarurire ... His life was filled with joy. And we are gathered here especially for the sake of Paul's son, Kashfa. Kashfa looks a lot like his father. He also has the same demeanor.

So this is a very important moment. We are waiting for Kashfa to come forward and sing... Do something... Anything. I am with everyone I love. My family. And uncle, who has organized all this.

We have come here to celebrate father's life.

He was a good person. Like you. Funny… Yes, he was better. And my mother, who lost... She lost her husband. It is a tribute to Paul, my father, and everyone else we have lost in the family.

There is one more thing I would like to say: She is the great hero of my life. She brought me to a better life in Norway, all by myself... I couldn't handle it. Alone, without knowing the language. She had lost her husband and family. Her best friends were gone.

So now it's my turn...

Jeg skulle gjerne reist tilbake til Norge hvis jeg fikk sjansen. Takk skal du ha. Ha det.

Ja, dette er Manigault House.

Hei! Velkommen til Joseph Manigault House. Melanie Wilson. Hyggelig å møte dere. Jeg visste ikke at vi hadde slektninger i Norge. Utrolig! Hvem var Manigault-familien? De var rike plantasjeeiere. De bosatte seg her i 1695.

Hva vet du om "den andre" Joseph? Jeg vet ingenting, er jeg redd. Den grenen av familien ble borte. Ingen dokumenter er bevart. Så det virker som han er avskrevet. Hva var grunnen til at han ble avskrevet? Eller skrevet ut av familiehistorien?

Den eneste jeg kan tenke meg, er at han levde sammen med en svart kvinne. Og de fikk åtte barn, så vidt vi kan se av manntallet. Men han er ikke registrert som Mollies mann i manntallet eller andre steder. Kusinen min, Andrea, fant ham i byregisteret.

Han er først registrert som hvit. Og senere står han som svart eller farget. Det er en interessant endring.

Disse to er grunnen til at jeg kom til Norge, Perceil og Ernest. Jeg fikk postkort fra mor mens jeg var på reise i India: "Ernest og Perceil bor i Oslo. Du kan besøke dem på vei tilbake." Han skulle bli i to uker. Han ble værende i to måneder.

Hvorfor det, da? Jeg møtte en kvinne. Jeg møtte moren hennes. Han drog til Juridisk bibliotek. Og der var Lill. Resten er historie.

Dette er graven til tippoldemoren din, min oldemor. Mollie V. Steward Manigault. Mollie var kjent i Charleston.

Etter hvert fikk hun råd til hester og kjerrer, så hun drev flyttebyrå. Hun var forretningskvinne? Hun hadde ungjenter boende hos seg. Og hun tegnet kjoler til hvite kvinner i byen. Jeg også lager klær. De sydde dameklærne hun tegnet.

Hun kunne spå i hånden og i teblader. Hun kjøpte bil i 1912 eller 1913. Du tror hun var den første svarte kvinnen i Charleston som hadde bil? Sannsynligvis, ja.

Hello, my girl! So nice to see you. You look good. I thought you'd be bigger. I still have a little belly, but ... Hey, Grandma! This is your great-great-grandmother.

It's Mollie Manigault, yes. In his old days.

It's easy to see that she was strong-willed, like you. My grandson and I have often frowned at each other. You have a bit of the same. It must be something that runs in the family. She was half Indian. She belonged to the Edisto tribe.

The Edisto Tribe? I have not known to which tribe she belonged. It is very small.

This is Joseph and Mollie. There was a powerful family in Charleston, the Manigault family. You know what? In the census they registered him as "Negro". Just to mock him. So Joseph had a hard time. He only got odd jobs. This lady had to keep the wheels turning, with eight children.

Is it just to walk in?

My name is Mira Craig. I have gone here and we had choir practice in this room.

Are you going to sing?

It's the best yet! I really liked it!

1997 is here. Who is this? Do you recognize her? It's Mira Craig!

He was in love with me.

They said you were here. They said you were on the second floor and I had to go up... Oh my God!

So nice to see you again! It's been so long since the last time. How many years is it? 15 years.

Do you want to join us and play basketball? Did they ask you to ask? I think I'll sit down. I'm getting old.

Waiting room for people of color Cinema for people of color

I live in Norway, in Oslo. They are from Norway ... Have you been there? Yes. I have been in Oslo. How long? One week. Did you come by cruise ship? No. It was my son's soccer team. Did they play in what is called the Norway Cup? Yes. An American team in the Norway Cup.

I would like to go back to Norway if I had the chance. Thank you. Good bye.

Yes, this is the Manigault House.

Hello! Welcome to the Joseph Manigault House. Melanie Wilson. Nice to meet you. I didn't know we had relatives in Norway. Incredible! Who were the Manigault family? They were rich plantation owners. They settled here in 1695.

What do you know about "the other" Joseph? I know nothing, I'm afraid. That branch of the family disappeared. No documents have been preserved. So it seems he has been written off. What was the reason he was written off? Or written out of family history?

The only one I can think of is that he lived with a black woman. And they had eight children, as far as we can tell from the head count. But he is not recorded as Mollie's husband in the census or elsewhere. My cousin, Andrea, found him in the city register.

He is first registered as white. And later he stands as black or colored. It's an interesting change.

These two are the reason why I came to Norway, Perceil and Ernest. I received a postcard from my mother while I was traveling in India: "Ernest and Perceil live in Oslo. You can visit them on your way back." He was to stay for two weeks. He stayed for two months.

Why? I met a woman. I met her mother. He went to the Law Library. And there was Lill. The rest is history.

This is the grave of your great-great-grandmother, my great-grandmother. Mollie V. Steward Manigault. Mollie was well known in Charleston.

Eventually she was able to afford horses and carts, so she ran a moving agency. She was a businesswoman? She had young girls living with her. And she designed dresses for white women in the city. I also make clothes. The sewn women's clothes she designed.

She could tell by hand and by tea leaves. She bought a car in 1912 or 1913. You think she was the first black woman in Charleston to have a car? Probably, yes.
